text:
Ok...I have to say that I tweeked this recipe big time. I used this recipe in addition to another butternut squash soup recipe. First of all, I used 2 squashes..cleaned and cut into 8 pieces..roasted them with olive oil, salt,and pepper and smashed garlic cloves for an hour in the oven..350. I then removed them from their skins..sauteed the onion and added 1 c. apple cider in addition to the chicken broth...and one peeled, chopped granny smith apple...and nutmeg, salt and pepper. I also have to say that I didnt use any of the cream cheese...the puree was perfect without..but I think I will add a small amount of 1/2 and 1/2 for a little richness. Excellent soup...thick, creamy and rewarding even if you dont use the cream cheese...way to calorie concious. Puree' in small batches in the food processor...be careful if its too hot!

text:
I served this soup for an Oktober Fest party and everyone loved it!  I roasted the sqaush on a sheet in the oven (cut in half and roast cut side down) for about 45 minutes at 375 because roasting brings out the flavor better. (Plus it is a lot easier than cutting an uncooked squash).  I used butter because I never use margarine, and I added slightly more cayenne than called for.  Everyone wanted the recipe.  It was fabulous!

text:
A quick and easy way to prepare this dish is to cut the squash in half, place each half face down on a plate, and microwave for about 8 to 10 minutes.  Then just scoop out the prepared squash and puree with the rest of the ingredients.  Half the cream cheese was plenty.

text:
In a word, INCRERDIBLE.  I made this the first time, with home made chicken stock (no salt, better flavour) and only one pkg cream cheese, 3x the amount of cayenne (we like a little spice).  It was to DIE for.  Used a hand blender to puree, turned out perfect, can't understand how anybody could have grainy soup, unless squash is 'old', which can happen this time of year...we found 1 pkg cream cheese was plenty with the proportion of stock listed.   The next day, was even BETTER, mellowed out, but seemed thicker-so we used (skim) milk to thin own a tad.  Next time I  made it, I doubled the stock, and added 2 pkg cream cheese.  Still outstanding!!  For me, a nice bowl of this and fresh sourdough bread is a comforting meal.  Used light cream cheese, worked out just fine.  Not to mentiuon this was SOOOOOOOOO easy!!!!! We will make this again...and again...and again....

text:
My friends and family realy enjoyes this soup.  I did make a few alterations however.  I left out the cream cheese ( greatly reduces fat content),  added in one pear ( or an apple can be used), and one potato ( a weight watchers trick,  gives soup the illusion of being more creamy).  I also broke up some spagettini into one inch bits and added this during the last 8 minutes of cooking.  Gives a different texture,  really great soup!!!!!

text:
I have tried this recipe and others probably experienced that peel and cutting a butternut squash is a pain unless u have a very very sharp knife I found it easier to pierce the squash and place it in the over at 400 degrees until it can be pierced with a fork smoothly then I let it cool and cutting it is a breeze and all you have to do is peel the tought skin off.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I had never made butternut squash soup before and I used this recipe as a starting point. I ended up making many alterations though, and I think they were definitely worth mention:

- roasted the squash for 45 minutes, cut side up, with a light brushing of olive oil
- used 1/2 a red onion, sauteed in *butter* then added 1/2 t marjoram, 1/4 t black pepper, 1/4 t cayenne, pinch of fresh ground nutmeg, and pinch of cinnamon, as well as four sage leaves
- chopped up a honey crisp apple and added that with 3 c water + 2 T chicken stock
- simmered this while the squash roasted
- added squash when it was finished and simmered for maybe 15 minutes longer (take out sage leaves before pureeing)
- pureed everything in a blender with only 8 oz cream cheese instead of 16 oz
- left on heat for 15 minutes longer to marry the flavors
- served with a dollop of cream cheese

My boyfriend is a professional cook and he declared this to be the best butternut squash soup he's ever had! He even bragged about it to his coworkers the next day. The added cayenne gave it a bit more kick, which we really loved, and the apple added another layer of flavor.

city:

text:
This is a huge hit with my family both at TG and Christmas. I peel, core and cube my squash, toss it in EVOO, sprinkle with salt and roast about 45 minutes in 350 for a deeper flavor. I chop a large Vidalia onion and mince up 4 cloves garlic and saute in EVOO. Add 4 to 5 cups veg stock (Instead of water) and leave the spices the same. I add in my squash + a peeled and chopped honey crisp apple and bring to a boil for a minute or two. I omit the cream cheese altogether. Blend in small batches and be sure to always cover top of blender with hand towel to prevent getting burned. I pour from blender to crock pot for parties. I've made this soup 3 days in advance and it only gets better. I also use it as a sauce over cheese ravioli and it's AMAZING! I'm a vegetarian and just love good recipes that don't call for artificial ingredients.

text:
The "TASTE" of this soup is 5 STARS but I found it WAY too thick to give it an overall 5 stars. I made the soup for a 2nd time today and am extremely pleased with the results!  I used 5 cups of chicken stock in place of the 3 cups of water and boullion cubes and also added 1 clove minced garlic along with the squash. I omitted the cream cheese all together this time & don't miss it a single bit. The soup still has an incredibly rich, creamy flavour without all that extra fat and calories. The flavour of the squash shines a bit more this way too.  Would definitely make my altered version again.

text:
I LOVE THIS SOUP! I gave 4 stars only because I've altered the recipe so much on the recommendation of the reviews here. 

I cut the squash in half and roast in (rub the cut side with olive oil, salt, pepper and a crushed garlic clove or 2, roasting the cloves right along with the squash) at 350 F for 40 minutes. While it's cooling, saute the onion. Then puree everything in batches in the blender. 

Also, I substituted a third cup light cream for all the cream cheese, and after having it both ways, I prefer the light cream. ENJOY!

country:
None
text:
We loved this soup!!! My boyfriend requested that I make it every night, and then threatened to run to the grocery store to get another squash!! I used the microwave trick and scooped out the squash with my ice cream scooper. I did only use 1 thing of cream cheese and lots of salt and it turned out great!! As for blending, I made the mistake a long time ago of not letting it cool long enough - splattered boiling soup all over myself! Pour a batch in the blender and the rest in a large bowl (I use my quart sized measuring cup) until heat isn't actively rising from either bowls (It won't create a pressure when you have the lid of the blender on). Start the blender off at the slowest speed and work your way up to puree, while keeping a towel over the top.

text:
This was exquisite. I oven-roasted all of the vegetables together with a couple of cloves of garlic and an apple, then put them in the food processor and into a sauce pan to simmer. I used only a dollop of cream cheese, but the soup was still very rich. To finish, I toasted some pumpkin seeds with a bit of roasted garlic and olive oil and sprinkled them over the bowls of soup, then drizzled over a bit of boiled apple cider mixed with water. One of the best recipes I have tried from Allrecipes!

This is fantastic. I cook the squash in the microwave first. Just split it, remove the seeds and cook cut side down in a half inch of water for about 15 minutes. Then it just has to be scraped out of the shell. Much easier than peeling and cutting up. I also think this is great without the cream cheese if you want to cut down on some calories.

text:
The recipe for this soup intrigued me when I first read it but the reviews convinced me that perhaps I needed to give this soup recipe a shot.  I have made this soup twice now and, in my opinion, it is absolutely delicious.  Everyone must try this recipe atleast a few times and I guarantee, you won't give it up.  Good recommendations were made to use chicken stock and 1/2 the cream cheese listed in the original recipe.  My soup ended up very rich and thick so I thinned it out a bit with low-fat milk.  Then, it was absolutely perfect.  I also froze a portion of it and used it another time - it was just as good if not better.  You will truly enjoy this soup, especially on a cold, winter day.  Please try it!

text:
This has been my go-to comfort soup ever since I discovered it this past fall trying to find ideas to use the squash that I received in my CSA share!

A couple of tips: 1)Only 1 bar of cream cheese & go for the reduced fat version (neufchatel cheese) to cut calories out... you will not taste a difference! 2) Definitely bake the squash at 350 deg for at least 45 min with a drizzle of olive oil, salt, pepper and lil bit of crushed garlic.. you will taste a slight raw squash after-taste if you don't since I've tried it both ways. 3) I like to add slightly more cayenne pepper (1/2 tsp total for a kick) and reduce the chicken boullion cubes to 2. 4) Costco sells the butternut squash already skinned and pre-cut in a 2 lb package for $5 (which is all this recipe needs). Slightly more costly, but saves a TON of time prepping. 

Enjoy :)

text:
I've made this several times and it always comes out wonderfully. It's very forgiving to little adjustments per your taste. I've tried roasting the squash, scooping it out, and burning my fingers (since I'm too impatient to wait for it to cool) and I've peeled it, bruising my knuckles on the cutting board a few times, and honestly, either way, it tastes just great, so whichever seems easier for you. I like the addition of nutmeg to the spices and I definitely use broth (chicken or vegetable). It also works well with the addition of other squash like Delicata, Kabocha, Carnival, etc. Enjoy!

text:
Hey folks this is SO easy to make if you don't cube and peel the squash first. Just cut a half inch hole in the squash (to avoid explosions) and microwave it whole until tender when poked with a fork, about 15 minutes. Turn a few times during nuking. Then just cut it in half, scoop out the seeds, and scoop out the cooked squash from the peel. VERY easy!
I halved the recipe, and used onion powder and garlic powder and no marjoram, 1 T of butter and 3 oz cream cheese. I just dumped the cooked squash and other ingredients into a blender and it was done. Excellent, rich and tasty!

text:
Fall Yummies! I made this soup yesterday.  I had two good sized butternut squash.  I used another reviewer's suggestion and halved them lengthwise and roasted them cut side down on a large cookie sheet in the oven for 45 minutes at 350.  This was perfect for scooping out the pulp.  I sauteed the onion in olive oil and a little butter.  I added 3 cloves of roasted garlic to that. Another reviewer used chicken stock/broth in place of the water. I did this also and it lent a richer flavor. I used about 4 cups of broth because I had more than six cups of squash and the soup was still very thick and hearty. I used only 3 boullion cubes.  I took the advise of several other reviewers and used only one 8oz. pkg. of cream cheese and I'm glad I did this because it would have seemed more like a cheese dip with another block of cream cheese in there.  I also added a couple of dashes of curry powder and that along with the cayenne gave this soup a robust flavor.  This was perfect for a fall afternoon pre/dinner appetizer. This is being added to my recipe box for sure.

text:
My husband rushed in from work after being attacked by a tenant's dog, sitting for an hour in traffic and getting sideswiped by someone who took off before my husband could get his license plate number.  The noise level in the house was unbelievable, as I had my neighbor's 4 kids over when she had an emergency.  My panicked husband still had to head out for another 2 appointments, and needed to find new pants as the dog had shredded the ones he was wearing.  Then I gave him this soup.  He stopped moving when he tasted it. He sat down. He actually smiled. He had three bowls. I fed it to the kids and for fifteen minutes there were no sounds but spoons clanking and lots of slurping. This is going in my cookbook as 5-Minute Magic Opium Soup. It's that good. Oh, also, I used frozen cubed squash and only about 4 oz cream cheese, powder consomme instead of bouillon, and used an immersion blender.  Tasted like magic and took about 5 minutes to prepare.

text:
This always get rave reviews.  Here is how I have chaned the recipe based on trial and error as well as other recommendations:  Cut in 1/2, remove seeds and spray with EVOO. Roast Squash in oven before pealing at 375 for 45 min. OR microwave 1/2 at a time meat side down for 8-10 min.  sub butter for margerine; sub parsley for marjoram; sub all spice for cayenne; add garlic; reduce cream cheese by 1/2; use inverted blender stick.

MADE ADJUSTMENTS! This is a five for sure, although I'd probably make some adjustments to cut the fat if this was going to be in the regular rotation.   If just making a couple times a year, it's perfect like this....  Bake the squash at 350-375 for 40 minutes or so, just till it is easy to scoop from skin. Do the onions with butter of course, I will use only 2 tbsp next time. I doubled the spices and halved the cream cheese. I simmered the onion, water, chicken cubes, and spices for 15 minutes, then added the already baked squash for 5-7 minutes to get the flavors together. Then blended with cc.  Excellent.  Would be a wonderful cup of heavy soup for an appetizer (small cup as it is THICK)

I made a few minor changes to this recipe and have made it for several occasions. Everyone always wants the recipe. I cut my squash into halves, drizzled with olive oil, and roasted on 375 for 40 minutes before moving on with the recipe. I used 4 cups chicken broth in place of the water/bouillon, a combination of cumin and oregano in place of the marjoram, and only 1 8oz block of reduced fat cream cheese. This soup is hearty enough to be served with some good chunky bread as a meal all on its own.

I LOVE THIS SOUP!!!  I have made this now four times in the last two months.  The reason I only gave it 4 stars is because I did make a few changes. I even ended up adding the cream cheese this time in an attempt to improve the flavor.  Broth is definitely the way to go!

text:
I made this the first time following the recipe to a tee. This time, I too tweaked it. I roasted the squash, but differently from other reviews that I have read. I cut off the top and bottom, sliced it lengthwise, scooped out the seeds, sprinkled with sea salt, ground pepper and dotted with butter. Then I put the squash in a baking dish, cut side up, put 1/4 inch of water into the dish, covered loosely with foil, and cooked for 45 minutes in a preheated 325 degree oven. When done, I kept whatever butter melted and put it in the stock. I added garlic powder to the onions, doubled the cayenne pepper and used half of the cream cheese. My hubby just told me that he thinks this is very delicious. It has a rustic flavor instead of an overly sweet, rich taste.

LIVING4HIM

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/151345.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is all about comfort. I cut my squash in half length wise, coated it in olive oil, salt and pepper and roasted cut side down on baking sheet at 375 for 45 minutes for a small one and added 15 minutes longer for a large squash. Let cool until easy to handle then scoop out flesh (trying not eat much). I used canned chicken broth. I increased the cayenne to 1/4 tsp and it leaves a nice little after heat. Bring everything up to a simmer then add squash. I used a stick blender to puree soup and when smooth as I wanted it I added 4 oz. room temperature cream cheese cut into cubes. Bring soup back up to simmer then serve. The small amount of cream cheese adds thickness and creaminess without being identifiable. Left overs will have to be thinned as the soup thickens as it cools. Great recipe.

text:
This is amazing! By the way 2 butternut squashes equals around 12 cups (oops!) so I had to double the recipe, however, I kept the same amount of cream cheese (2 pkgs). I baked the squash at 375F for 45 minutes, next time I'll bake it a little less because they were a pain in the butt to peel! Also, I used homemade chicken stock and butter. However, this was SO much work because I didn't have an immersion blender.. I had to throw it in the food processor in batches and it got really, really messy. So beware. Other than that, this is definitely a keeper and I'll definitely make it for company some time.

text:
Again, I don't know if it's truly fair to rate this 5 stars when I adjust the recipe per other people's comments (love that aspect on this website!), but I absolutely love this soup! I roast the squash prior to cubing it (split in half, remove seeds, spray cut face w/ non-stick spray and lay face down on cookie sheet, roast in 375 degree oven for about 45 minutes-- makes peeling and cutting so much easier, plus it brings out the flavor of the squash). I also OMIT THE CHEESE altogether (made it both ways and decided I liked it better w/out it). Very tasty and great for those fall afternoons!

text:
This is the best butternut squash soup I have ever had--perfect for Thanksgiving, or any chilly Fall night!  Rich, creamy & relatively easy to make.  I roasted the squash, and actually used the meat from 1 1/2 squash in the soup.  Based on the reviews I read I used only 8 ounces of light cream cheese (neufchatel) and it was still sinful!  I also substituted chicken broth, oregano & red pepper flakes, for the bouillion, marjoram and cayenne, respectively, and it is incredible.  Impressive for guests.  Beautiful color--I garnished with finely minced red pepper and flat leaf parsley flakes, and it was gorgeous!  I'm so grateful I have leftovers!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This soup was amazing! The only reason I only gave it 4 stars was because I did make some changes. I cut two squashes in half, drizzled with olive oil and rubbed with 8 cloves of minced garlic and sprinkled with salt. Baked in the oven at 350 for 50 minutes and scooped out the squash, added the cooked onion, water, bouillon, & spices and brought to a boil. I then added the cream cheese to make it easier to blend. Once that had melted I added everything to the blender in batches. I also used only 1 1/2 packages of cream cheese but I would only add one if I made this again.

text:
I love this recipe!  I tweaked it to make it low sodium:  Instead of bouillon and water, I added 3c low-sodium broth.  I added 1/2 tsp nutmeg, pinch of cinnamon, 1/2 tsp cayenne, and most importantly, replaced the cream cheese with just four ounces of a creamy chevre (I used Boucheron).  This gave the soup more flavor but brought the sodium content down to about 600 mg sodium for the entire dish, and less than 100mg of sodium per serving!  My husband had thirds!  Delicious.

text:
This soup is awesome.  I usually add a couple of pears or apples and some ginger, and cut way back on the cream cheese (1/4 to 1/2 what the recipe states).  If I'm out of cream cheese, I just add milk instead.  It freezes well, too, just add the cream cheese or milk after reheating.  For an easy garnish, you can toast the cleaned squash seeds in a 350 degree oven with 1 tbsp of olive oil and some salt and cinnamon until they start to brown.

I couldn't figure out why all the recipes for butternut squash soup on here instructed to just chop the squash and boil while EVERY review said to roast first! I did both, doing the other steps exactly the same... the roasted squash soup is REMARKABLY better! More flavor, better flavor. Not roasting it first makes it an 'ok' but rather bland bowl of pureed orange mush. Roast your squash people!

userID:

Display Name:
NikkHoff
isPro:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I give this 5 stars, but only with how I tweaked it.  To make it less labor intensive, I microwaved the squash (after piercing it with a fork) for 10 minutes, turning every couple of minutes.  This softened the skin to make it easier to use a knife to peel off the skin.  I could have halved it, microwaved it longer, and scooped out the insides instead since this is how I "roast" butternut squash, but I didn't think about that until I was halfway done with cutting it in chunks.  I used one whole small onion and 4 small cloves of garlic (my husband loves garlic and onion), sauteed them and then I added a dash or two of each (ground):  sage, ginger, nutmeg, coriander, celery seed, and cloves.  Then followed the rest of the recipe.  I also used only 1 package of Neufchatel.  Mine turned out creamier than any other butternut squash soup I've ever tasted.  I never understood why people blame the texture of their creations on the lack of fat in neufchatel since its essentially the same as full fat cream cheese.  I've never had that problem (even with my award-winning cheesecake).   If you want a thicker soup, reserve about a cup of the cooking liquid while you're pureeing the chunks of squash with the cream cheese.  That way, you can judge how thick its going to turn out.  I ended up pureeing and adding the rest of the liquid in the end.  If it didn't turn out creamy enough, you need to either cook the squash longer or puree it longer.  This would make a great sauce on cheese raviol

I did use a little curry powder and used only 1/2 block of cream cheese (4 oz).  I'll make this again and again!

I read through many other reviews of the recipe and decided to go with just one pack of cream cheese. however when I finally got to the recipe after a long day of cooking, I realized I only had 5 ounces of cream cheese and it was plenty and probably the bare minimum needed. It was a great hit and really nice that it was so easy! and oh yeah- I didn't even use butter, used olive oil out of habit and didn't even notice the difference.

YUMMY.  Like so many others, I tweaked this recipe quite a bit.  Because of time limitations, I baked the squash in a pan of 1 inch of water, skin side up - yesterday.  I also added 1 large sweet potato that I cooked in advance as well.  Today I melted the butter added the onion - 1 whole - and besides adding the marjoram, I added about 2 teaspoons of curry powder.  I only used about 3/4 of a package (6 oz.) of cream cheese. Which gave it a rich, but not overpowering taste.  It needed a little salt, and is so incredibly tasty.  I was making it in advance for a party but I like it so much I know I'm going to have to make another batch.

text:
Freshly grated NUTMEG is a very tasty addition to this delicious soup. Wow.....what a great recipe. 

For an EASY WAY TO CUT THE BUTTERNUT SQUASH: microwave the squash for 2-3 minutes. That softens it.

 After that, cut off each end and set upright and peel downward. Cut it in half. Cube the top 1/2, then scoop out the bottom 1/2 and cube it.

I cut the recipe in 1/2, making 3 servings.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This 5-star rating is more for the rejuvenated recipe I created, of course using advice from a ton of other reviewers. I used the same ingredients as this one, except I cut out all but 1/4 of the cream cheese and used 2 cans of chicken broth instead of bouillon.  Other additions included 2 peeled and diced summer zucchini (if you don't have enough BNS), a celery stalk (diced), one granny smith apple (cubed and peeled), nutmeg and about 1 tbsp of light whipping cream. To prepare it, I roasted the butternut squash in the oven for 1 hr at 400 F with salt, ground black pepper, and crushed garlic on top. Once it was done, I sauteed the onions, celery, apples and zucchini for 10 minutes.  After that I added the butternut squash and let it cook in the pan for a few minutes too, since it wasn't completely cooked in the oven. Then I poured in the chicken broth, marjoram, cayenne pepper and nutmeg. I let that all come to a boil and simmer for about 20 minutes.  Finally, I added the cream cheese and whipping cream and blended it up. So delicious, my new favorite dish!

text:
Husband and 4 year old son love it!  I have also made this in the crock pot.  Let cook on low for 6-8 hours until squash is tender.  Puree with immersion blender.  Add cream cheese and let the hot soup soften it for 5 minutes.  Puree again with immersion blender to blend cream cheese.  I freeze leftovers in muffin tins for perfect individual serving sizes.  Freezes and reheats well.

Absolutely delicous.  This will become a new, but low fat comfort food for me.  It tastes much more caloric than it is. I also doubled the cayenne pepper and used only 8 ounces low fat cream cheese.  Was glad to read reviews that this freezes well.

country:

text:
This is absolutely the best butternut squash soup recipe, EVER.  I did modify this recipe just a tad.  As another viewer recommended roasting the squash with olive oil, salt, pepper and garlic for 1 hour @ 350.  This was absolutely the key in making this soup stand out from all the others.  I also only used one 8 oz package of cream cheese.  Once I added the 1st package I really didn't see the need for the second one.  I also ommitted the cayenne pepper, only because I don't like it, the garlic from roasting the squash gave this recipe the kick that it needed.    

I do not have a food processor so I used my hand held wand blender, worked perfectly.  I don't recommend using low fat or fat free cream cheese only because I think it will take away from the purpose of using it in the soup.  Sometimes a recipe needs that fat to make all the other flavors combine.  

If I could give this recipe more than 5 stars I would.  Hands down, just awesome!!!! I can't wait to share it with friends and family.

text:
My sister-in-law made butternut squash soup a few years ago for the holidays and I loved it so much I asked for the recipe.  She conveniently kept "forgetting" to give it to me so I searched on-line for recipes.  I tried a few over the years and there was always "something" missing - they all tasted good but not quite GREAT.  

She made it again last month and that time I noted the flavours.  I thought the missing ingredient was possibly some kind of cheese so when I found this recipe calling for cream cheese, I thought I'd give it a try.

BINGO, I'd found the missing ingredient!!

I basically combined my previous favourite recipe I'd found along with this one to come up with my final product.  I roasted the butternut squash; left out the marjoram (didn't have any); used only half the cream cheese; and added 1/2 head of garlic, a medium carrot and a stalk of celery for added depth of flavour.  I have to say, it turned out even better than hers!

text:
This recipe was VERY good...however, I would give it 5 stars with the following revisions. I like my soup a little more on the sweet side. I added 1 Tbsp. of Nutmeg, a dash of ginger and about 1/2 cup of Apple Cidar. I also added about 1/4 cup of brown sugar. OMGoodness!!

I prepared this as a "soup de jour" for Thanksgiving, so I made it the day before and let the flavors "merry" together in the fridge overnight and warmed the next day!! Holy Cow this was awesome! My family gave rave reviews over this one!

I also only added 1 pkg. cream cheese and I roasted my butternut squash in the oven for approximately 50 minutes on 450.

If you want a really good, rustic, fall recipe...try this one! You won't regret it!!

So good, so good!  I did deviate on the preparation, but I used all the ingredients, except for the cayenne pepper (not my fave).  I only used 2 T of marjarine to saute the onions, roasted the squash with olive oil, and cut the cream cheese by four.  I only pureed half of the squash with the cream cheese and then mashed the other half with a potato masher.  I like to chew a little bit of something in my soup.  This was the best.  I had a pumpkin soup similar to this ten years ago and LOVED it.  I have been searching for the recipe ever since.  Now that I have this one, I will try it with pumpkin next.  Yummy, yummy!!

PS. When making this another time, I found out to NOT use fat free cream cheese.  DOES NOT blend well.

text:
I've never made butternut squash soup before, but I took the advice of others and also cut the cream cheese down to 4 ounces, and used neufchatel instead to cut some additional fat. 

I roasted the squash -- cut in half lengthwise, sprayed the cut side with PAM and roasted it, cut side down, on a baking sheet at 375 degrees for 45 minutes. This cut the boiling time in half and I think added some great flavor. Next time, I might try adding an apple to blend with it -- this is a very forgiving recipe. Even my husband, a very picky eater who doesn't like "adventurous" foods loved this and asked for seconds!! Even better as leftovers. Definitely a keeper!

text:
I have made this dish using all sorts of squash but butternut and pepper are the best!  I half the squash first, drizzle each with olive oil and rub coarse salt, freshly ground black pepper and minced garlic over each half.  Then I wrap each one in aluminum foil and bake at 350 for 30- 40 minutes (depending on size of squash).  I also half the amount of cream cheese.  Great for autumn picnics.  Loved by all!

city:

country:
None
text:
A couple of variations that I did with this recipe:
It takes a little longer, but the night before I cooked the soup, I roasted the squash in the oven until they are soft.  This makes it easier to get the "meat" out when you're ready to make the soup and it gives the soup a fabulous nutty roasted flavor.
Also, instead of adding cream cheese, I added heavy cream, it makes the soup much lighter, and If you have family members that are slightly lactose intolerant, they can usually handle the heavy cream over the cream cheese (or add Lactaid, which works very well).
But this soup recipe was very easy to make and very delicious. It is my new favorite soup.  Thank you for submitting it!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is just plain fantastic. To address complaints of grittiness, I don't know if I read it here or elsewhere online, but I'd recently learned it can have something to do with the age of the squash. I myself have made this three times now, and one attempt was perfectly smooth with almost no texture outside of smooth and creamy. The other two did have a bit of grittiness. I couldn't figure out for the life of me what was different, so I researched and learned the younger the squash, the more tender. (No different than zucchini.) So they're more likely to blend down smoother.

Either way the flavor is PHENOMENAL. I've also used this as a base for a pasta sauce with chicken apple sausage, with great success. So happy to have found this!

Display Name:
Susan Cann Lydem

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1527829.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was delicious.  I chopped each butternut squash into large chunks, coated with a little bit of olive oil and seasoned with salt and pepper.  Roasted at 375F for about 1.5 hours until the squash had caramelized and became very soft.  The squash was so sweet and almost buttery when it came out of the oven - so good!  Sauteed the onion and 1/2 of a cortland apple and then added that, the butternut squash and the stock to the blender in batches and pureed until smooth.  Heated it gently in the stock pot with 4 ounces of neufetchel (1/3 less fat) cream cheese.  Added a little more cayenne than the recipe called for and adjusted salt & pepper to taste.  

Some things I may try when reheating leftovers: 
Add just a dash of nutmeg and/or cinnamon.  
Adding just a bit of very finely minced fresh sage from the garden.  
Saved the seeds from the squash and may make some spicy toasted seeds and top the soup with it.

text:
I read the top reviews so I tried the recipe first without the cream cheese (or half n half as another reviewer suggested).  I have to admit that I liked this best without the cheese.   I liked it ok with a touch of cream, but just a tiny amount.  also, since I had it in my csa box, I substituted a leek for an onion.  I added a half of celeriac and a small fennel bulb and two peeled apples.  It was glorious.  I didn't taste the fennel since it was such a small amount.  The celeriac made it really creamy.  this soup is really filling.  I made a lot of it and it will freeze well (without the cheese or cream).  Awesome recipe.  I'm glad I tried it. 5 stars even with the changes, since I might have passed on this if it didn't get such high reviews.

In an attempt to eat more fresh produce this year I bought 2lbs of peeled and chopped butternut squash from Sam's Club and decided to try something new. I scaled the recipe down to 4 servings and ended up with 6 - 1cup servings. I didn't have marjoram so I subbed oregeno. I also roasted the squash for 25 minutes in the oven, per the suggestion of others. The first night the soup was just okay, but after a couple of days the soup was amazing. I had it for lunch everyday for a week, and the 1 cup was just enough to really satisfy me. I will definitely make it again, and let it sit for a day or two before I plan to eat it. Thanks!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious! Although I sort of used this recipe as a base and used what I had on hand at home. Here's what I did:

Sauteed the onions in about 3 TB of olive oil. Once they are soft, added in some minced garlic. Then throw in the squash (I used two bags of pre-cut, cubed from Trader Joe's) and a can of chicken broth. Add salt, pepper and fresh thyme (about 1 tablespoon; dried would probably work fine). Cooked for about 25 mins until the squash is tender. Take off stove and added about half a package of cream cheese. I used whipped because that's what we had. Taste for seasoning; add more salt if needed. Put all in blender and serve!

text:
Another amazing review for this amazing soup!  I can't believe how fast, easy and forgiving this recipe was.  I just roasted the left over squash from thanksgiving in the oven for 40 minutes, dumped it on top of sauteed onion and garlic, used oregano since I didn't have majoram handy, used a combo of 1% milk and chicken broth and let it simmer for about 20 minutes.  Added 2 oz of reduced fat cream cheese, pureed in the blender and voila!  My four year old wants to have this "every single dinner"...success!

country:
None
text:
This is a great little starter recipe--provides the basics for how to make butternut squash soup and can be tweaked in many ways.

I baked my squash first, with cinnamon, cloves, brown sugar and a little butter before adding to the sauteed onions and spices.

I then used neufchatel cheese to cut down the fat and calories, and half as much as called for.  I used a mix of half and half and skim milk to help thin it out and find rich, but smooth consistency.

I'm looking forward to making it again this winter and playing with the proportions and spices again!

This will the only butternut squash soup I will be making!  Really, really amazing!

With all the 5 star ratings of other viewers I feel I must have goofed on this recipe somehow because the flavor was just okay.  I want to try it again sometime and if it turns out better I will change my rating.  Anyway, Mary, thanks for submitting this recipe as it seems to be a top rated recipe by others....I just need to get it right!  7-13-16:  I tried this again and this time I oven roasted the squash and then scooped the softened squash into the onion mixture.  After adding the squash and cream cheese to the pot, I used my immersion blender until smooth.  This was not only faster, but less to clean!  I also used my own chicken bone broth and the end result was really good.  Tho next time  I am only going to use 1 package of cream cheese because it was a little too rich.

text:
Like the other reviewers, I roasted the squash first.  Then, I added it to the broth to simmer and, after 20 minutes, I was able to easily mash it with a potato masher/ricer in the pot, which I think was easier and less messy than using a blender/food processor.  I realized at the last minute that I did not have marjoram, so I substituted thyme and a little cumin, which I thought tasted great with the cayenne.  Really rich, creamy, lets the great taste of the squash shine through.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/343794.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i made quite a bit of modifications. in the end, this is what i did (using this recipie as a guide)   4-5 servings:  I roasted one medium butternut squash in the oven for about 45 minutes.  I seasoned it with salt, pepper and olive oil before i put it in the oven. I did this the night before and scraped the flesh out of the butternut squash and put it in the fridge overnight for easy prep the next day.  In a medium pot, i browned 1 med. onion.  Added  2 carrots, 2 celery, 1 large sweet potato. Let that cook down for 5-7 minutes.  added enough chicken broth to cover the veggies.  Bring to a boil and simmer for 40 minutes.  Using a hand blender, i blended the soup in the pot and added more chicken broth until i got the consistency i wanted.  I threw in salt, pepper, cinnamon, all spice, groud cloves, and ground cayenne pepper.  Sour cream to garnish.   such a versitile soup that you can modify to your taste!

Made a few changes, added 2 carrots, 1 large or two small garnet yams and some celery. Roasted the squash, yams and carrots in the oven to carmelize. Sauted the celery with the onions. I also have made this using a little fat free half and half because I didn't have enough cream cheese, same results.

Display Name:
MANOMES

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Butternut squash soup is so versatile it's hard to mess up, but here are my suggestions after many, many times using this recipe. Halve and roast the squash with the 1/2 onion (quartered), 1 carrot (1/2 inch slides), 1 apple (peeled/cored/quartered) and 2 garlic cloves for 45 min. Use chicken broth (reduced sodium) instead of water/bouillon, cut cream cheese to about 4 oz. Add a few pinches each of ground curry and ground ginger with the chicken broth. Stir in 1/2 c.  half and half or milk just before serving.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Yummmmy!  I did modify the original recipe a little bit.  I substituted green onion for the onion, fresh cayenne peppers (3 seeded and chopped) for the ground cayenne pepper.  I sauteed the green onion, chopped cayenne peppers and two gloves of fresh garlic in about 2 T of butter until tender.  I roasted the squash in a 375 oven as others had suggested prior to adding it to the pan with the sauteed onion mixture and 3 cups of chicken broth.  I had to simmer the mixture about 10 minutes so that the squash was the right consistency to blend with my hand blender (right in the pan).  I also added a little salt and fresh ginger. I blended in about 4 ounces of reduced fat cream cheese as the last step. My boyfriend raved about the soup!  This soup will find its way to our table a lot during the upcoming cooler months!  Delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe according to the directions until, like other reviewers, it came to the cream cheese. I put in one box, half the proposed amount, and I still found the cream cheese taste to be really overpowering. I wish I would have put in 1/4 of the amount and then added more to taste. Also, like others mentioned, the finished soup was extremely thick, like a dip. I probably added another 3 or 4 cups of chicken stock to thin it. All in all, I would make the recipe again because it's really easy, but I will make some major tweaks. Oh, and here's a note for the other beginner cooks out there: one butternut squash is more than enough to make the soup. You do not need to purchase multiple squash. 6 cups sounds like a lot, but a squash goes a long way.

text:
SO SO SO darn good!  A friend made this for me first and I was skeptical because I hadn't had good experiences with this type of soup in the past.  But it was so good.  I got the recipe from her and then found it here.  I did much the same as others have already mentioned: I baked the squash in the oven versus boiling it.  I used one medium onion and sauteed it in olive oil versus butter.  I cut the water in half, but used all the chicken broth.  I didn't add the cayenne pepper, but did extra basil and seasonings.  I also only did one package of cream cheese.  Turned out great.  Great flavor and not too squash-y!

I put the squash/onion/broth mix into the food processor and gave it a try before adding any cream cheese. It was beyond amazing. It's really hard to believe that something so simple could be so delicious. I was afraid, however, that by not adding the cream cheese I'd be missing out on something. I added less than half of the amount listed in the recipe, but even that small amount was enough to kind of ruin the recipe. It's delicious enough before adding any cream cheese, so just leave it out. Cheers to our health!

Very yummy, but I also tweaked it a bit. -I roasted the squash, cut side down for 45 minutes. -I only used about 1/2 a block of fat free cream cheese. -I added "most of" a can of vegetable broth to the finished soup, as I found it to be too thick. -I laced it with fat free half & half before serving. -And I served it with garlic cheddar biscuits... delicious! My husband made this and it came out delicious tasting but runny, maybe because he only used 4 oz of the cream cheese?  I think it had enough cream cheese, it didn't overpower the squash.  My husband did a few things differently:  like I said less cream cheese, he roasted a whole onion and the butternut squash, he also roasted a whole head of garlic and used that, he used 3 cups of chicken broth instead of the water/bouillon combo, and he added some nutmeg.  Like I said, the flavor was excellent, we just need to work on the consistency the next time we make it.  It's definitely a side soup type of thing, not hardy.

text:
This was very simple to make & was a perfect side to smoked pork chops!
I gave this 4 instead of 5 simply because, like quite a few other reviewers, I made some changes to the written recipe.
I, too, roasted the squash in the oven.  IMO this not only adds flavor but adds to the ease in preparation.
I'm doing WW so I reduced some of the fat & calories by using fat free cream cheese and only half of the called for amount.  I also used fat free margerine.
I thought the soup was very rich & creamy.  I believe using the full amount of cream cheese in the recipe may have overwhelmed the mellow flavor of the squash.  
With these simple changes, this recipe came in at only 3 points per serving according to the WW recipe builder.  Def. a keeper for my winter soup recipe box!

city:

country:
None
text:
I tried this soup today, with a few mods...  I put a whole small yellow onion in the food processor to chop it pretty fine and added all of it.  I didn't want to hassle with cooking a whole squash, so I used a frozen pkg of cooked squash that was 14 oz cube from Safeway.  I used a single can of chicken broth, also 14oz.  Only used 1 tsp of chicken bouillon granules, skipped the marjoram and cayenne but did add a dash of nutmeg and garlic.  I only added half an 8oz pkg of cream cheese since my batch was so much smaller.  Pureed in blender until smooth and served with a dollup of (not Daisy) sour cream.  It is very good.  Along the lines of other creamy soups like tomato.  Would be very good with grilled cheese sandwiches.

text:
This was unusual. This was my first time cooking and eating butternut squash, so I didn't really know what to expect it to taste like. I followed the advice of others by: 1) cutting the squash in half, drizzling it with olive oil, sprinkling salt and pepper and roasting it. 2) I also roasted a head of garlic at the same time and threw that in later on. 3) I then picked up with the recipe and used homemade chicken broth instead of water & bouillon. And 4) I used half of the cream cheese called for - definately enough! I found it did need a little extra salt and seasoning in the end. It was also a little tart, so I added some sugar to taste.  Okay, but I doubt I will make it again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe isn't excellent, but it's good.  I was alittle disappointed given all the great ratings.  I followed the recipe except I did bake the squash instead of cutting it into little pieces.  Butternut squash is extremely hard, so cutting it into small pieces would have been a nightmare. I sliced it long ways, placed it cut side down in a pyrex, put alittle water and covered with foil -- baked at 350 for 40 min or so.  It was very easy to scoop out at that point and continue the recipe.  If your going to make this, I suggest you prepare the squash the same way.  Like I said, it's worth a try, but I really don't think I'll make it again.

text:
This was excellent, however, I did alter the preparation a bit. As others did, I roasted the squash and only used 1 pkg of cream cheese. I forgot the squash while it was cooking so it roasted for about an hour and 15 minutes, but it didn't burn and seemed to give a better texture. I used a can of chicken broth and added 2 Tbsp of nutmeg. I didn't have the time to mix in a blender so I just put eveything in a large pot and used a hand-held mini-blender to mix. I think it definitely helped in the texture although it was still a little "grainy", not that we minded. It was still a little rich, but excellent. However, when it was reheated for lunch the next day, it was not very good...way to sweet and the taste seemed to have altered a bit. Maybe the ingredients had a chance to "meld" together and alter the flavor. Overall, I great recipe. Thanks!

This is one of our favorite soup recipes!  I added minced garlic and 1/2 cup of white wine to the butter & onions.  I used half of the cream cheese this time, but would probably use more next time since we like it thicker & richer.  I also reserve a cup or more of the cooked squash and add it to the blended soup for interest and texture.  I garnish each bowl with shredded sharp cheddar and a dollop of cream cheese.  Even my picky 2 year old likes this soup, especially when I add some cooked brown rice to his bowl.

I love the soup! I am down to making it without measuring anything. Blend everything then add the cream cheese on high for about 30 mins. I personally believe that it is better slow cooked. I have also make it with an apple cinnamon version. I boil 1 apple and a cinnamon stick with the broth from the soup for about 30 mins, blend and then add. Gives it a totally different experience! Sometimes I add cooked ground sausage and peppers in the middle to again add a different taste and it actually goes well with the soup! Women tend to love this soup, men not as much :/

Loved it!!! . . . But like most cooks I did slightly alter the recipe. userID:
2475159
Display Name:
Chickadee
isPro:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/190437.jpg
city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this many times now. My husband calls it restaurant quality and always asks me to make it when we have company he wants to impress, LOL. More importantly, even my mother-in-law was impressed!  I do only use 1/4 of the cream cheese called for though, otherwise it is WAY to cream-cheesy.
Here's what I do: Cut squash in half and bake for 1 hour at 350 (cut side down on tin foil). Let cool while sauteeing onions and some garlic. (Sometimes I cook the squash the day before). Add one peeled/cored apple. Scoop out squash into pot. Depending on how ripe/soft the squash is, it's sometimes easier to cut the squash into strips and slice the skin off. I actually do this more often than not. Add broth. Add seasoning (marjoram, nutmeg - 1/2tsp, cinnamon - 1 tsp, dash of cloves, S&P, garlic powder). Simmer for an hour or so, then drop in the cream cheese for a few mins to soften before blending with a hand immersion blender. Done!

text:
I will give 5 stars because this recipe is always my base but I don't follow it word for word, as is 3 stars. As you will see with many of the other reviews. This morning I decided I will never 'cut up' butternut  raw again because my hand is still sore. My husband got a 4.5 pound squash - 2 pounds is about six cups. Cook in the oven before... Taste better and so much easier. 
You must LOVE cream cheese to add that much. You can also substitute heavy cream, milk, potatoes, or a milk/flour/butter thickener. 
This soup is simple and tasty - great for a cold Wisconsin winter.

country:
None
text:
This soup is DELICIOUS!  My family loved it. The cayenne pepper gives it a great zing.  It's really creamy and filling, and leftovers reheat well in the microwave. 
 
I didn't change the recipe, but I AM a shortcut taker...  I used three 12-oz boxes of frozen butternut squash--it's already cooked and pureed, so I heated it in the pot with the other ingredients until the squash wasn't frozen anymore then brought it to a boil, and eliminated the additional 20 minutes cooking time.  I tossed the cream cheese in and blended with an immersion blender right in the cooking pot so I didn't have to transfer the soup back and forth.  

The flavor is wonderful. Just for variety I'm going to add cilantro and curry next time as it seems it would make a good Indian-style soup as well.  I'm sure there are many possible variations, but try this soup as-is first!

I agree with other reviewers--roast the squash in the oven so the peel comes off easily.

text:
I loved this recipe.  After reading many of the reviews, I made a few changes too.  3 Acorn Squash, that I cut in half and baked in the oven for 40 minutes at 375; chopped three shallots and four carrots and sautÃ©ed both in a stick of butter,  Once soft, I transferred to by Slow Cooker/Pressure cooker; added 4 cups of chicken base, 1 tbsp. of ground ginger, 2 tbsp. of brown sugar, salt and pepper.  Took the squash from the oven and scooped all into the slow cooker.  Cooked slow for 2 1/2 hours and them blended all in the cooker, finally added 8 oz of whipped cream cheese, blended that in and covered slow cooker for another 1 1/2 hours.  Husband loved it, so I dared to bring a pint to my Mother...Received two thumbs up from her.
Thanks to all for weighing in on the great recipe.

This soup is one of my first and it's FANTASTIC! Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Made this 3 times in the last two weeks... Thanksgiving everyone loved it so thank you! Made it again for my girlfriends family and once more for a holiday party this past weekend. People were asking for the scoop on how to make it. 

Followed the ingredients aside from water and bouillon, I used free range low sodium chicken broth, which was a nice touch. And the 2nd time I decided to try a low fat Philly cream cheese and I used about 15 oz the taste was not even really noticably different. So for the health concience thats something to keep in mind. 

third time I made it for double the serving about 14 people, doubled the squash and the broth kept the cream cheese at 16 oz for the double servings and it was still 2/3 fat Philly cream cheese and yet again it was a hit. 

Also, I used one of my favotite ingredients, Tumeric, eyeballed it as I do everyting else but it was about 1/8 Tablespoon for the smaller pot and about 1/2 tablespoon for the double recipe, adds some really nice floral notes and helps wo compliment with a nice white wine of your choice. 

I also doubled the Cayenne... Yum 

Hope this helped someone.

My neighbor gifted me a butternut squash that was close to 2 1/2 lbs, so I decided to give this a try.  I halved, de-seeded and roasted the squash at 350 for about 40 minutes.  After roasting I could easily scoop the flesh out into the soup pot.  I added 3 1/2 cups of chicken broth rather than the bouillon/water, along with the remaining ingredients and simmered for 20 minutes to meld the flavors.  I pureed the soup with my emersion blender right in the pot.  After tasting the soup I decided to skip the cream cheese altogether.  I thought it tasted great without it.

I thought this recipe was fantastic, but I too made some changes.   I roasted a 3 lb squash with a peeled granny smith apple for 45 mins at 375.  I sautÃ©ed 1 medium onion chopped, 1 peeled chopped carrot, and 1 Yukon gold potato, 2 cloves of minced garlic in the 4T butter.  I used 4 c low sodium chicken broth, added the the chopped up roasted squash and apple, added 1/2 t marjoram, 1/4 t cayenne pepper, 1/4 t rubbed sage, and pepper.  Simmer for 10 mins.  Added salt to taste.  PurÃ©ed in the blender w/ only 4 oz of cream cheese.  Was delicious, but I wanted a bit more bite so I added 1 T of apple cider vinegar.  Truly spectacular.  It is a thick soup, but I like it that way!

text:
This soup is absolutely delicious.  Just as good as you would expect with all the 5-star reviews.  I followed suggestions from some other cooks & added an apple to the soup, and only one 8 oz. pkg of cream cheese.  I used Neufchatel (light cream cheese) and chicken broth instead of water & boullion.  Also, I used oregano instead of marjoram because that's what I had on hand.  I started to give it only 4 stars because my husband wasn't as crazy about it as I am.  But as far as I'm concerned it's over the top good!  You must try it!

country:
None
text:
This is the first time I've ever made Butternut Squash Soup and it was fantastic! I followed a few tips from other reviewers and it was perfection. I roasted my squash first which made peeling easier. I used 4 Cups of chicken broth and added 1sp. of curry powder, a cinnamon stick and a bayleaf for some extra flavor. I omitted the marjoram which I didn't have. I didn't have cream cheese either so added 1/2 and 1/2 before serving, plus some brown sugar, which made the soup sweet at first, followed up by the heat from the cayenne and curry. AMAZING!

text:
Best squash soup I've ever made! Halved the recipe, using 3 c. butternut squash, and wild onions. Definitely the easiest way to make this it to halve the squash, put in Pyrex with butter and 1/2 c. water and bake until tender, then add other ingredients and blend. Since I only used 3 c. of the cooked squash, I made pumpkin bread with the rest. Very good recipe!!!

text:
Everyone seems to love this but I didn't care for it. I think the cream cheese may have been its downfall. I roasted the squash first for 40 minutes at 375. Had no marjoram so used poultry seasoning instead which is primarily marjoram. It smelled fabulous while cooking. I only added half the cream cheese but it was still very overpowering and the soup was way too thick and too sweet for my taste. Without the cream cheese it may have been quite good, I'd suggest pureeing and sample first before adding it.

text:
I haven't had or made this soup before so I wasn't sure what to expect, but the boyfriend was happy with it and so was I. I roasted the butternut squash with olive oil, salt, pepper, and garlic as some of the other readers had suggested. I also used half of a granny smith apple and, instead of cream cheese, just a bit of heavy cream did the trick. I regretted using the apple at frst because the soup was too sweet, but you can use something acidic to balance that out - I threw a little splash of balsamic vinegar in and it balanced it well. I also added more spices then the recipe called for.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was good, but I was surprised by how cheesy it was, even with only half the called for cream cheese.  I followed others' suggestions about roasting the squash first, instead of trying to cut a hard squash into little cubes.  Simply sliced it in half lengthwise, and put on greased pan in oven at 375 degrees for 45 minutes.  Other than that, I followed the recipe as written except only using one (8oz) package of cream cheese, being a tad scant on my pepper measurements (for the kids' sake), and using base instead of bouillon cubes. The kids liked it (which was a nice surprise,) but the overwhelming flavor was cheese, not squash.  I think this recipe should be called Cheesy Butternut squash soup.  I can't even imagine how cheesy it would have been with two bricks of cream cheese!  Anyway, overall this soup was good, but just not what I was expecting.

userID:
7703789
Display Name:
Sara J.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe 3 times now and have finall figured out how I like it... I found a 2# container of cubed butternut squash at costco so that simplifies the recipe exponentially.  Because it's more squash (I found 2# = 9c. squash,) i just increase the rest of the recipe 1.5x.  I don't have dried majoram and found that I can sub with less oregano.  Also you could probably cut down the butter (who uses margarine??) so it's more calorie friendly... I don't have chicken buillon and used chicken stock instead (add in salt to taste if you do this!)  I also followed suit and cut the cream cheese and added in a little (light) sour cream!  Lastly, i only use a dash of cayenne and monitored the black pepper cuz I've found it can be overwhelmingly peppery otherwise.  For added spice, i use my best friend Tapatio to taste :)  the soup is thin, so i followed the directions on the side of the corn starch box on how to thicken my soup (though still a delicious thinner soup!)  I make this every other week since it freezes well, so i split the soup over 2weeks and freeze half of it. Super delicious!

text:
Great beginning of a recipe.  Like others I cut the cream cheese in half and this was plenty.  I also used chicken stock instead of bouillon cubes and water.  I add fresh grated garlic salt and Tony Chachere's creole seasoning.  The soup was a big hit.  For a more hearty meal you can cook some small noodles in chicken stock and butternut squash puree and add it with chicken to the soup.  My husband loved this addition. Serve with corn bread and you have a complete meal.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't have any onion so I just left it out.  I cut one butternut squash in half and drizzled it with olive oil, salt and pepper then laid each half cut side down on a cookie sheet and baked for 20 minutes at 375.  I dissolved 3 cubes of chicken bouillon in 2 cups water then added the peeled and cut up squash, nutmeg (didn't have any marjoram), and cayenne pepper.  I boiled this for a minute or two then scooped out the squash into the blender, using some of the liquid from the pan.  I blended this with 3/4 of 1 package cream cheese.  My mom and I loved it!  Sweet, creamy and just a little spicy.  I plan to freeze it to enjoy later.  Thanks for the recipe!

I always roast the squash in the oven with some olive oil and sea salt to bring out the flavor.  I have found that 1 package cream cheese usually works and makes the soup super creamy!!  Is it bad to crave squash soup??  mmmmmmmm :)

country:
None
text:
This was absolutely delicious. I've never made this type of soup before. But I had bought the cubed, ready to use box of butternut squash from Costco and needed to use it up. I read through the reviews and based upon the majority of the reviews, I used only one package of cream cheese and used chicken stock instead of bouillion. I also added a couple of turns of freshly grated nutmeg at the end. I used my immersion blender because frankly, I hate the whole process of moving from one container to the other. I also cooked it longer, more like 30 minutes, before adding the cream cheese. I think this soup is adaptable in many ways, using an apple, white wine etc. I'd give this recipe a 4 1/2 stars if I could. Give it a try!

text:
I love butternut squash soup but can never get it to come out just right. This one was easy but I changed it to fit my tastes. I don't like spicy- I prefer sweet, so I skipped the spices and added brown sugar while the squash was boiling. Being vegetarian I changed the chicken bullion to veggie broth. When the squash was real soft I put a few ladles full in a bowl with a package of cream cheese & blended with a hand mixer. I kept adding ladles full of squash until all was blended then put it back in the pot and cooked on low for about 15 minutes. SO SWEET and GOOD!! The cream cheese was what I've been missing all these years!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
I only needed 1 squash, because that was give or take 5.5 cups. I peeled it then hollowed it out with a grapefruit spoon like I would a pumpkin, even taking an extra layer off of the stringy part. Then I chopped it into 2 or 3 inch pieces. But, since it's being boiled I definitely think it should be chopped smaller. Really though, the bigger pieces didn't make a difference.  I followed the recipe to a T, boiling everything (but cheese) for 20 min. Then I put half in the processor with 8oz of cream for about 2 min. Moved it to a side container and did the same with the other half.   It had way too much cream cheese! I really only used 1.75 containers, because my instinct said it would be too much cream cheese. It really overpowers the squash.  This recipe may be worth trying again someday if I cut the cream cheese by 1/4, and maybe add more from there.

Yummy! Made a few alterations based on other reviewers' suggestions. Oven roasted squash first, cut in half, olive oil, garlic powder @ 350 for 50 mins. Increased chopped onion to 9 tbsp & added 3 cloves minced garlic. Used olive oil instead of margarine (healthier). My whole squash was more like 5 cups but it still worked. text:
Savory, creamy, rich and complex.  This soup is very good and very easy.  I had some left over chunked butternut squash that I used for a different soup recipe (we did not like that one!) so I was looking for something that I could do with it, with other ingredients that I had on hand.  I had already boiled the butternut squash, so followed the recipe, except I did not cook it all together for 20 minutes.  I just put it all together, carefully measuring out the right measurements of squash and water.  I put it all in the blender and had wonderful soup in about a minute.  This is seriously like a five star restaurant soup recipe, it would be wonderful served in demitasse cups as a starter to a meal.  Thanks for posting, I will use this recipe again and again!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this soup once a week for the past 4 weeks. The girls from work love it. I have to admit I have changed it a bit.  1. Roasted butternut squash (cut in half, clean out seeds, rub with olive oil, place face down on cookie sheet, roast 350 degrees for 30-40 min or until easily pierced with a fork.  2. At the same time I roasted a whole clove of garlic and added it to the soup. ( cut top off with knife, sprinkle with olive oil, wrap in foil. roast same temp and time as squash) 3. I used chicken broth not bouillion. 4. Used half the cream cheese. 5.  Added garnishes... green onions, bacon, and grated cheese. 6. Used a immersion hand blender in the same pot!!   Feel free to add in this recipe. I have used apples and white wine too!!  This recipe is a must try and share with friends!!

I am sitting here on a Autumn Sunday afternoon eating this soup, and it couldn't be more perfect. I too took some suggestions from others experiences.  I only use 1/4 of 8oz pkg of cream cheese since I find any more makes it too rich.  I first roasted the squash which made prep work so much easier.  I also find the soup a little thick, so I add about 3/4 c of additional chicken stock at the end.  Just enough to thin it a bit. My favorite soup!  Hope you enjoy.

text:
I loved this recipe!  I opted not to add cream cheese and instead scooped in a tablespoon of low fat sour cream.  I also added a sweet potatoe.  To speed up cooking time, I cut the squash lengthwise and cut up the sweet potatoe and microwaved it for 15 mins on high in a small dish with about 1 cm of water in it.  It comes out soft.  I just peeled it and used a potatoe masher in the pot to mash it all up.  It was amazing!! Even my kids gobbled it up:)

text:
Really enjoyed making (and eating) this last winter. It's a versatile recipe; I easily made it both vegetarian and relatively healthy. Threw together a quick veg stock with vegetables I had on hand. Followed some other reviewers' advice and roasted the squash cut in half and face down (@350, 45min). Allowed it to cool, peeled it easily. Omitted the cream cheese. Added a dollop of fat free Greek yoghurt on top along with a sprinkling of fresh thyme. Roommates and I are looking forward to making this again soon!

Ahmazing.  I've never done a squash soup before, and don't have a food processor, so I was a bit worried.  I shouldn't have been, a blender works fine.  This recipe was super easy!  I added some garlic with the onions, used coriander because I didn't have any marjoram and doubled the black pepper, so it definitely has a kick.  I also used less than 4 ounces of cream cheese and it's plenty creamy!    I try to only eat meat a couple of times a week, so this will quickly become one of my filling winter staples!

text:
Delicious soup. My blender with the glass jar kicked the bucket, so I got out the potato masher instead and mashed it in the pot, then added the cream cheese. I've had this recipe 'blendered' before, and mashing did not detract from the overall soup at all. It came out fairly smooth. I used homemade chicken stock, and one package of light cream cheese, and it was just right. I also didn't have any marjoram, so I substituted with oregano and a smidgen of thyme and sage (dried leafy, not powdered). Great soup, will definitely make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious! To make it even easier, cut the squash in half, and place it cut side down in a baking pan with about an inch of water.  Cover and bake at 350 F for about an hour or hour and a half. This will make it so much easier than trying to peel it!  When cool, scoop the insides out into a blender or food processor and combine with the cream cheese to puree.  Add this to the other ingredients and heat through. I  used chicken broth instead of water and boullion and used a little crushed red pepper instead of cayenne. I also used only one package of light cream cheese. This was quite easy and truly delicious!

text:
I've made this many times. The nice thing about this recipe is, the measurments don't have to be exact.  One nice size squash equals about 4 cups.  I use 3 cups of broth and only 4oz of cream cheese.  I like to season mine with nutmeg, curry powder, white pepper and thyme. It took me a few times to figure out why mine was grainey. I have found that blending in a blender, in small batches rather than a food processer will make a smooth (not grainy) soup.

I made this for my fiance and she LOVED it.  I tweaked the recipe much like someone else who commented.  I didn't use any cream cheese.  I halved and seeded two butternut squash. userID:
4201648
Display Name:
greenthumb
isPro:
False
followersCount:

4
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really good basic recipe, except I made a few changes.  I roasted the butternut squash, cut side down with a little olive oil, at 350 for 45 minutes.  I also roasted 2 cloves of garlic at 350 for 20 minutes.  I carmelized the onion in a saucepan.  After the squash and garlic were done, I peeled and cut the squash into large cubes.    I disolved the boullion cubes in hot water.  Then I put roasted squash, roasted garlic, carmelized onion, and 1/2 cup heavy whipping cream and pureed, adding boullion water slowly.  I poured the puree into a stock pot on the stovetop and simmered while I seasoned with salt, pepper, cayenne, pinch of thyme, pinch of cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg.    I served with grilled chicken and swiss sandwiches for a warm meal on a snowy night.  My husband and son loved it!

text:
Wow, this soup was delicious! I disagree with the reviews claiming it was bland, I thought it had the perfect amount of seasoning--more would have obscured the delicate squash flavor. The only changes I made was 1/2 the cream cheese as many have suggested, butter instead of margarine, and broth instead of bullion cubes. I made part of it with vegetable broth to accommodate my vegetarian sister and the difference was barely detectable. I took this soup to a party and received lots of compliments on it, and I will definitely make it again--a very cozy soup!

text:
Our dinner party was raving about this! We had some tasty bread to dip in the soup, but honestly it seemed like it took away from the amazing flavor! Changes we made: We used butter instead of margarine, chicken broth instead of water & boullion, and neufchatel instead of cream cheese. We microwaved the squash before cutting it into small peices and throwing it into the pot. After we added all the ingredients, I smashed the squash with one of those potato mashers (still in the pot). We added the cheese directly to the pot, and it melted right in. We also added some orange peel for flavor. Definitely will be making this again, many times!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was wonderful.  I tweaked it a little.  I used 1 squash, quartered and roasted for 45 min at 350. Then I cooled it, skined and chopped it. Added it to a pan with about 2 1/2 cup chicken broth, 4 T butter, 1/2 t pepper, 1/4 t nutmeg, 1/8 t cayenne, and dash salt.  I also added half of a diced granny smith apple.  I let that all cook for a while, then used the potato masher, and let it cook a while more.  I cooled it then pureed it in the blender.  Back to the stove, added maybe 1/2 c cream and heated back up.  YUMMY!!  Even DH who swears he hates squash said he would eat again.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was delicious!!!  I used half the cream cheese like other readers suggested.  I think the amount the recipe calls for would have been too much. I slow roasted the squash in the oven after brushing it with olive oil.  It smelled yummy!  Nuking it in the microwave would have been faster, but the microwave is known to zap some of the vitamins and minerals out of food, so I opted for the longer process.  I added ~ 1 1/2 tablespoons of minced garlic, 1 teaspoon of cinnamon, 1/4 teaspoon of ginger, and 1/4 teaspoon of nutmeg to give it more flavor.  It came out a little too thick for what I'd call soup, so I thinned it with lowfat milk.  It was just the bomb!  My picky family asked for seconds!

text:
Wow!  This soup was incredible!  I followed others advice and roasted the squash and used a hand emersion blender to break down the clumps.  My husband is a meat and potatoes guy, so I served it with toasted beef sandwiches, but it was hearty enough for me to eat as a meal.  (I used the 2 pkgs of cream cheese which made it thick and very creamy) 
Thanks so much for sharing this great recipe!   

I also tried this recipe with canned pumpkin instead of squash and it turned out great!  I added a little bit of brown sugar, some ginger and cinnamon and it was a huge hit!  The pumpkin made a slightly thinner soup, but could have also been because of light cream cheese.  Either way it was delicious!!   Thanks for sharing the recipe!!!

text:
Delicious. I used two small pumpkins instead of the butternut squash, roasted them in the oven at 375 for an hour. I sauteed the onion and one clove of minced garlic in 1 TBS olive oil instead of the margarine. I brought all the other ingredients (3 cubes vegetable bouillon instead of chicken) up to a boil, then added the scooped out roasted pumpkin, brought back to a boil, let simmer for about 5 minutes, then added the neufchatel, which I halved per the other reviewers' comments. Next time I will go a bit less still...I think 6 oz will be about perfect. I did add a touch more cayenne and black pepper after I tasted it. It was delicious. I really agree with everyone else: I can't imagine this with the full amount of the cream cheese, which is why I gave it 4 stars. But it was a hearty and satisfying meal with some salad and french bread. Will definitely be making it again.

I made this for my family and they went out of their gourds over it. However I omitted one of the cream cheeses and added about 1/2 cup of half-and-half instead. I also baked my squash halves (open-side down 350 for 1 hour)instead of peeling and saute-ing. Much easier to scoop out the cooked squash mush than to peel and dice and I think the roasted flavor adds to the richness. Definitely will make this one again!!!

Yummy! As per other reviewers suggestion, I cut the squash in half lengthwise, scooped out seeds, drizzled olive oil, salt & pepper and roasted for 45 mins. at 350. I peeled the skin off before pureeing. Next time I might try the microwave for mid-week cooking. I also used chicken broth instead of bouillon. Didn't have the cayenne pepper so I added just a dash of chili powder. As others have suggested, I used one package of cream cheese & it came out splendid.

text:
Good recipe - I rated a 4 instead of a 5 because I cannot imagine how thick it would be if I had followed it exactly and used a pound of cream cheese!!!  I had a couple cups extra of squash, so adjusted the amounts as necessary.  It was quite thick even before I added the cream cheese - about the consistency of heavily whipped potatoes.  So I just went with 4 ounces, and still had to add about a cup of water to thin it out.  I generally like a thick and hearty soup, but it was just too thick.  Good flavor, though!  I think next time I may try adding some buttermilk instead of the cream cheese to get the tangy taste.

text:
Great soup! Perfect for a chilly autumn day. Used some suggestions and roasted 2 lg. butternut and a lg. onion for about an hour, until I could see the squash start to brown. In a blender pureed squash, onion, cream cheese along with 4 tablespoons butter, and a 48oz can of chicken stock. By the way, 1 package of cream cheese was enough to make it thick and creamy. I was a little heavy handed with the peppers but I do like it spicey.. :-) Made 8 qts and sent some to Mom, sis and the neighbors.  All agreed it hit the spot. Made it twice before writing the review.  Thanks and enjoy.

None
text:
This soup is absolutely amazing!! I didn't roast the squash like some suggest, just peeled it and cut it up. I didn't have any marjoram or cayenne so I didn't add it, but I did add some salt and parsley. I also added a cubed potato and 2 cut up carrots. I also made it once where I added a zucchini. It was very delicious and I only used about 3 tablespoons of light cream cheese- still nice and creamy (but it also tastes good without any cream cheese at all). You could probably cut up and add other vegetables too, like red peppers, and it would taste great! One tip though: you can use other varieties of squash other than butternut, but choosing one with a smooth skin, rather than grooved or bumpy skin, makes it much easier to peel. Thanks Mary!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was fantastic! I used one block of cream cheese but that is because I increased the servings a bit. I ended up using two good size butternut squashes, roasted in the oven cut side up in two baking dishes with a quarter inch of water and covered with foil. I sprayed them with butter spray and sprinkled on kosher salt, pepper and garlic powder. Roasted at 400 for an hour until tender. I used 3 cans of roasted garlic flavored chicken broth. Next time I won't even need to bother with the onions and butter and saved calories to boot. The flavored chicken broth gives it plenty of good flavor. It was excellent and everyone at the party I took it too really enjoyed it.

text:
This recipe is so wonderful, definitely a favorite, definitely a keeper.  I have made it several times and find I prefer it without the cayenne. I use white pepper instead of black, add a teaspoon of brown sugar, and use fat-free cream cheese (not nearly as rich, so you can use the full amount).  I then sprinkle on a little dried parsley for color, top it with a dollop of fat-free plain yogurt (a mild brand like Dannon), and not only does it taste incredible, it is gorgeous soup to look at  - and healthy as well.  Everyone LOVES it, even people who hate the sound of the word "squash"!

an absolutely scrumptious lunch served along with Dee's Health Bread

and it was creamy and delicious. Two pkgs. of cream cheese would have
been much too fatty and rich for my liking. Great recipe!

text:
After reading several of the earlier reviews, I cut the squash in half, put it cut side down on parchment paper in the microwave and cooked it for 8 minutes.  It had to cool briefly before I could handle it but it was then very easy to scoop out.  Although already cooked, I put it in the pan with the onion and butter and cooked it longer, then used a potato masher before I put it in the food processor.   I also used chicken broth rather than water and bouillon cubes and used less than half of the cream cheese.  We've just come from a cruise where I always love the soups they offer  -- as someone else said, even my husband likes this and now I plan to serve it for Thanksgiving.   :>)

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
However you make this soup you should save all the seeds and scrapings.  While the squash is cooking,  saute 2 or 3 minced shallots in some butter or oil for a few mins. till soft, then add the seeds and scrapings  and saute a couple mins. more ,  add 4-6 cups of water ,and bring to a boil, then simmer covered for 30 mins.  , strain out the seeds and add this broth to your finished soup before pureeing.  It will give it a lot of extra flavor.

text:
Made a couple minor modifications, but it make this soup delicious! Here are the changes I made:

-cut squash into 6 pieces, coated with oil, salt, pepper & minced garlic & roasted at 350 degrees Fahrenheit for one hour
-added a chopped Apple & sautÃ©ed with onions
-added 3 sage leaves whole simmering & removed before blending
-used chicken broth plus 1 tsp Better Than Bouillon instead of water & bouillon 
-only used 4oz cream cheese
-garnished with Mexican crema & crumbled bacon

text:
I loved this soup I brought it over for a girls night :)  I made a few changes.. I followed the advice of everyone only using half the desired amount of cream cheese as it was very creamy and thick with just one brick.  I also didn't have any marjoram so I added a few fall spices to mine to make it flavourful.  I added quite a lot of cinnamon,  a pinch of ground ginger,  a pinch of ground Clive's and also a few pinches of nutmeg I put them in all to taste,  but the Cinnamon is the most important so if you are going to add anything I would say Cinnamon is the game changer!  It was awesome and really easy to make!  Highly recommend this lovely soup!
