None
text:
Love this soup! It is easy to prepare and freezes well. I use cut up squash (organic from Costco). Since it is seasonal, I make several batches and freeze in Mason Jars. I put everything in the pot except the cream cheese and the milk that I add instead of so much cream cheese (I cut the cream cheese in half and add a cup of milk per batch). Once it is cooked, I put it in my food processor and then back to the stove to add the milk and cream cheese. Once it's blended, cool and into the jars...so easy! Great recipe!!!

I had to convert this to metric (because I am in Italy) and I think I added too much water, so it was a bit liquidy. I halved the cream cheese as the recipe suggested as an option, and it was great. Follow th recipe exactly, because all the other suggestions are just personal preferences and won't really improve anything.

It was amazing! Amazing! My husband, who doesn't really like to eat any of the American soup I make even gave his approval. 

So In all, I don't think the proportions I used were dead on, but I can't wait to try again! Perfectly toasty for a cold winter night. I also may add some broccoli next time just to see how it turns out.

favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I combined 2 Butternut Squash Soup recipes. Roasted 2 medium squash with 2 cloves garlic for about 45 minutes.  Meanwhile sautÃ©ed small onion, a carrot, a stalk celery in about 2 TB butter. Add salt. Let that sautÃ© on low for about 15 minutes. Peeled and sliced thinly a potato and an apple. Added to veggies. Scooped the squash into pot along with roasted garlic. Then added chicken stock to cover plus about 1/2 cup apple cider. Brought to a boil and simmered for about 1/2 hour. Added little nutmeg and cayenne.  Added about 2 ounces lite cream cheese. Stirred till melted. Used immersion blender till smooth and creamy. Correct seasonings. I ended up adding about another 1/3 cup apple cider and little salt.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! As others, I roasted the squash and pulled the skin off. Took about an hour for mine to get really soft. I used less water/bouillon initially as I knew I could always thin it out. I had no marjoram, so used 1/2 the amount called for of oregano but I don't believe it added any distinguishable flavor. I used half sodium-free and half regular bouillon cubes. Finally, I followed the advice to use half the amount of cream cheese and thought that was sufficient. It was pretty thick, so I ladled some into a container to freeze before thinning the whole batch. I then thinned with additional water/bouillon mixture and added cayenne to taste. I thought this was fantastic as it was, but we were at an event a few weeks ago where there were butternut squash soup shooters with a candied bacon piece. THAT was divine! Would be wonderful for entertaining!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I tried this last night and have to say like many others, I did add/change it. First, I cut out half the cream cheese (I'm not sure how I could it eat with two!) 
I also did not cook it the way it said to start. I cut thick slices of the squash and baked them with a little EV olive oil and sprinkled with garlic, cinnamon and cayenne. 

I used butter and not margarine (next I won't use so much either). Then I added low sodium chicken broth (about 3 cups but I should have added more because it felt a little thick). I think it depends in the size of the squash but mine was from the garden and huge! I used it all. 

Then I realized I didn't have marjoram so I just threw in whatever sounded good. More cayenne, cinnamon, a pinch of nutmeg and ginger and black pepper. 

The only other thing that I would do is chop the onions finer or blend them with the squash. It doesn't bother me but I know my mother wouldn't like onion chunks. 

Overall, this was so good and my first attempt was a hit with the hubby!

text:
This was a very easy recipe. I brought it to work for a function and had to hand out the recipe to a few people as well.  Listening to the other reviews, I cut the squash in half and put a little butter on it then baked it on a flat sheet with a little water in the bottom for an hour at 350 and it came out perfectly.  I also halved the cream cheese as one package was plenty and it turnes out really creamy.  Last change I made wasnt intentional. When I went shopping I forgot the broth, luckily I had some beef buillion at home and thought id give it a shot using that instead of chicken.  I havent made the original so I dont know if it was an improvement or not but it was amazing. Will definitely make this again. The cayenne gave it just the perfect touch.

Like many people suggested, I did tweek the recipe .  I halved the squash ( used one squash) rubbed it with olive oil salt and pepper then baked face down 350 for 1hr not covered. After I removed the skin cubed it and placed it in the pot with real chicken broth mixture ( softened onions and celery). I halved the amount of regular cream cheese and added a pinch more of cayenne. Used my immersion blender  and voila. Served it last night for thanksgiving dinner at friends,,,everyone loved it! I served it with herb buns ,,,,sooooo goooood!

My favorite squash soup recipe! Followed the recipe and really liked it! Modified later by adding 1/4 tsp nutmeg and substituting 1/4 cup half and half for the cream cheese and loved it even more! I make this all the time in the fall & winter months, it's a hearty soup that tastes great!Thanks for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is fabulous!  I was looking for a savory butternut squash soup and this recipe fit the bill.  I will say the marjoram is a must as it adds a subtle taste that should not be missed.  I make a vegetarian version using vegetable broth - one 32 oz container - and I do not use the chicken boullion cubes and I do not add the water that the recipe calls for.  This soup always gets rave reviews.  As with other reviewers, I find it easier to roast the squash first, then scoop out the pulp for this soup.  I also do not use more than 4 oz cream cheese and I use an immersion blender at the end to make a velvety smooth soup.  Thanks, Mary, for a fabulous soup I have made many times now.

text:
I was not sure I would like this but decided to try it since I had a butternut squash and only 1 8oz cream cheese -low fat. I roasted the squash by halving it and baking face down for about 40 min at 375. It was almost soft when I took it out but was able to peel and cube. I then continued and cooked it on stove for about 20 more min to blend flavors. Then I used my vitamix and put in cream cheese and soup. From there I poured it back in the pot  and It sat on my stove most of the afternoon. I just reheated for dinner....yum! Better than I thought! I also used quart of chicken broth instead of water and chicken bouillon.

Just made this recipe - it was REALLY easy.  I tweaked it slightly in that I had to use some items I had on hand.  I used red onion, I used cajun seasoning instead of cayenne, I used butter instead of margarine.  I only used 4 ounces of cream cheese (that seemed to be enough).  To top it off I put a swirl of Agave nectar and Tapatio for a sweet and salty kick.  Very good.  Would probably add a little garlic and more salt and pepper next time. :)

text:
Great recipe with a few tweaks.  As other reviews suggested, I cut the squash in half, de-seeded, and roasted (cut side down with skin on) in a pan with some olive oil and salt/pepper for 45 minutes at 350 degrees.  I then let the squash cool and peeled/cubed it.  I think roasting really brings out the flavor.  I also made it vegetarian and substituted the water/bouillon for 3 cups of vegetable broth and double the cayenne pepper.  It was delicious!  Very rich so if you like thinner soup, I would suggest using half the amount of cream cheese.

This was delicious!  I was faithful to the spirit of this recipe, but I made it in the crock pot by adding all the ingredients to the crock, cooking on low for 6 hours, pureeing with an immersion blender, adding cheese, pureeing again.  I used one LARGE butternut squash (I think the squash was around 5 lbs whole, and yielded 10 cups of cubed squash).  I also increased the onion to one whole onion, chopped, and substituted 16 oz Philadelphia Lite Cream Cheese for the 16 oz cream cheese called for.

text:
Wonderful recipe.  I did tweak it a bit to feed my family of 7.  I took 2 butternut squash's, split them in half, took out the seeds, and microwaved each 1/2 for about 8-10 minutes each, then peeled off the skin in order to get to the meat of the squash.  I also used about 8 cups of water and 8 bouillon cubes.  I also doubled the spices and included salt.  I kept the cream cheese at 2, 8 oz. pkgs.  I found that this helped to keep the soups creamier.  Other than these changes, I followed the recipe the same.  Next time I think I might add some garlic to the onions.  W topped off the soup with some sour cream, bacon bits, and shredded cheese.  I will definitely be making this recipe again.

text:
I thought this recipe was great! Perfect with homemade bread on a chilly fall night. I did take some suggestions from other users and omitted the cream cheese, used only 2 tablespoons of butter (not margarine), used chicken broth instead of bouillon cubes, added a dash of nutmeg, a cup of apple cider, and one granny smith apple. I also roasted the squash in the oven first, with EVOO, salt and pepper, and garlic cloves. My husband and daughter thought it was a tad too thick - but they tend to be picky eaters. Regardless, it was enjoyable :)

text:
I used this recipe as a base and added to it. Like a lot of reviewers I cut the cream cheese in half, I used butter instead of margarine, and home made chicken stock instead of bullion and water. I added two small granny smith apples, garlic, cinnamon, nutmeg, and ground clove. I just eyeballed the amounts based on what I like. I added a little cream to thin it out but I think I'll add a little more stock, it's getting lot thicker as it cools. I was really surprised at all the flavor. My husband doesn't like butternut squash and he liked this !

userID:
5064878
Display Name:
SarahM
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/836883.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow this was wonderful :) For those concerned about using the cream cheese, just use fat free or low fat. I used just one of the Philadelphia cream cheese round 250 gram containers, 95% fat free. I did not have any apple cider but I did have apple butter and I used about a cup of that, plus half an apple. I used one butternut squash and I also did what another reviewed recommended and put olive oil, salt, pepper, and smashed garlic cloves on the squash. I baked it for an hour at 375 (I have a very old oven :). I sauteed the onion, added in water, chicken bouillon, apple butter, and spices (except for marjoram which I did not have. I added 1/2 tsp nutmeg which was nice. Also I used crushed red pepper in place of cayenne and it still gave it some nice heat). I pureed the squash and garlic cloves with the cream cheese in small batches as recommended. I then added the pureed squash and cream cheese mixture to the soup on the stove and let it simmer at low heat, stirring until it was all nice and mixed up. I won't add any salt at all next time as it was perhaps a tad too salty. And I think next time I may add apple cider or more apple for a bit more sweetness but overall it was soooo good! :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Roast squash in olive oil, salt, and pepper face side down instead of the skillet idea. Till tender of course. The skin should peel off very easily when it's done roasting. Oven temp around 375 to 350. Depending on how much time you have. Also only one package of cream cheese should be used. Two is way to much. Also add some nutmeg into the mix it creates a much more complex pallet. And much more delicious. Since this recipe is so creamy I added fresh cooked bacon bits to add a little diversity in texture and some chopped chives as a garnish. It helps to keep you interested in eating. The guy loved it.

text:
I roast my squash for about 45 min at 400 degrees after brushing it with melted butter and adding salt and pepper to get that sweet and nutty flavor out of the flesh.  I kept everything else the same but only used 8 ounces of cream cheese, not 16, I felt it was going to be way to rich if I used it all.  Also, a side note, if you roast the squash, you only need to simmer it with the rest of the ingredients for about 5-10 minutes since it's already been cooked.  Enjoy!

userID:

Display Name:
mrskomplex
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
116
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I had butternut squash soup n an upscale restaurant this fall and I have been craving it ever since.  This recipe came really close.  I used it as a base and following the lead of other reviewers, tweaked it a bit.  I roasted the squash with olive oil and dusted it with cinnamon.  I scooped out the tender flesh after it roasted about an hour.  It smelled great baking.  While it was baking, I sautÃ©ed onion, garlic, and fresh ginger in margerne.  I added chicken broth and then added the squash.  As far as seasoning, I added 1/2 tsp of curry, 1/4 tsp of cayenne pepper and black pepper.  I then used a submersion stick blender and blended the mixture in the pot.  I then added 1/2 a block of cream cheese and blended it as well.  It was super creamy and smooth, but was missing a little something. So I added a about 1/4 cup of cheap beer and about 2 tbsp of brown sugar.  This brought it over the top!  This was great!

text:
After reading through the reviews here, we only used 1 package of cream cheese and also added 1T of garlic powder, 4 tsp of chili powder and 1 tsp. I think the garlic and chili powder were an excellent addition! Before adding those spices, I wasn't really sure I liked this soup at all and now I LOVE it!   We didn't saute the onion, just sliced it up, threw it in and used the immersion blender right in the pot - very easy and yummy soup!

text:
You really don't need any cream cheese at all in a butternut squash soup, so unless you are trying to fatten up starving wilderness survivors, I'd leave it out!  The suggestion of apple cider or juice in another review is a good one as a fruity variation.  Personally I like it savory with prebaked squash and garlic. If you have time to make your own vegetable or chicken stock, it's a huge improvement on chicken cubes. Isn't butternut squash an absolutely wonderful rewarding vegetable to cook with?!!!

country:

text:
This soup is VERY creamy, pudding-like texture! I made 6 people proportion, and found that 18oz of cream cheese was a overkill. That's is the secret why this soup stands out from the rest. You put cream cheese on grass and it will taste good! 8oz ( 6 portions)is just right, won't sacrifice the taste nor the texture . 
:advice:
1. Roast two halves cut side down @ 350f for 45min
2. Add some butter in squash pan (use some of the butter ,easy for this recipe, it will all comeback into the pan)

3. Take all the juices from the squash pan, collect it with some broth, in the pot it goes

I gave it 4stars for the calorie fat. I am a sucker for healthy, looking for more thing good and healthy

text:
I've made this three times so far and it's been wonderful every time.  I've always used real butter.  I've never added the marjoram - we just don't have any.  The first two times I only used one cream cheese, but I cubed the squash as instructed. The third time I used two packages of cream cheese and baked the squash, and it was much better-tasting.  Each time I've used Better Than Bouillon instead of bouillon cubes.  I've always used my blender and the texture comes out very nice.  My nine-month-old loves it!

text:
Now I have never once had butternut soup- so I don't have a baseline.  I had many butternuts in the garden this fall- and was looking for a way to use them.  I used 8oz of reduced fat cream cheese and found that it is still very thick and rich- could probably use only 4oz. I also had some opened chicken stock to use instead of bouillon. I also used a pinch of oregano since I did not have any marjoram. Next time- I will be roasting the squash first in order to make cutting it easier- I think I bruised my hand with the knife!

text:
I have had butternut squash soup at the best restaurants in Manhattan and Brooklyn, and this recipe (with one change) is by far the best. 

The only thing I do differently is cut the cream cheese serving in half and use the less fat package. 

It is also nice to add a touch of cinnamon at the end, to each person's bowl.

If you rate this recipe less than 4 stars, you are making it wrong, or you might just not like butternut squash soup. :)

Thank you for sharing!

text:
You can make this recipe more exciting by adding a can of corn and some roasted russet potatoes. I diced my potatoes and drizzled them with olive oil with a little salt and pepper before roasting them in the oven. Add the corn and potatoes as while you heat the soup after it's been blended. Makes it heartier and SO good! P.S. My son loved it with CHEEZITS on top!

madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
19
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took a large butternut squash, quartered it, and put it in the oven with a few potatoes and a few large carrots(washed but not peeled).I sprinkled on some olive oil, added about 1-2 tsp kosher salt and 4-5 whole cloves of garlic. Then I stuck it in the oven at 350 until the veggies were soft. After the veggies were cool enough to touch I peeled them and added any juices at the bottom of the casserole to a large pot along with the veggies. Then I added the broth, and other ingredients in the original recipe. I also added the slightest amount of clove to add a bit of kick.

text:
Awesome!  My husband, "the chef" modified this, by adding celery, garlic, honey, nutmeg, cinnamon, and some sugar.  He advised me to adjust to taste buds, turned out great!  I agree with other reviewers only need 1 8oz package of cream cheese.  I used fat free, I could not tell a difference.  Lots of flavor and creaminess.  Used two huge squash and made a gallon of soup.  Also, a lot of reviewers roasted the squash first, but I followed the recipe and boiled until I had a great stock base with flavor and the squash was rtender enough to puree.  Will make again definitely!

text:
We loved this soup, and don't ordinarily love squash.  I followed the lead of some others and roasted the squash.  I used two squashes, sliced in halves.  I splashed with olive oil and coarse ground pepper and kosher salt.  Roasted cut side down for 45 minutes.  The flesh was super easy to scoop out and use.   I used vegetable buillion to make it a vegetarian soup.  I used 1/2 the amount of cream cheese to make it a bit more calorie friendly.   I didn't have cayenne, so I used about 1/2 t. hot pepper sauce.   I will surely make this again.

text:
As a soup lover, this was absolutely amazing! I made a few changes as some other reviews suggested. I roasted the squash beforehand, sauteed 3 celery stalks and 2 cloves garlic with the onion and also used half the cream cheese. I used whipped cream cheese but I'm not sure if that mattered much. I didn't have any marjoram and added turmeric then topped the soup with fresh chives when I was ready to serve it. Delicious!!
Review:

text:
I used 1 pack of cream cheese and it was more than enough.  I'd suggest using 6 oz or just add heavy cream.  I poked holes every 2 inches going around the squash and stuck in microwave for 2 min.  Easier to cut that way, but that was the hardest part.  This soup was very creamy, rich and tasted like a very good restaurant's version.  Husband loves it, but I'm giving it 4 stars because of too much cream cheese.  Also used extra dashes of cayenne and nutmeg.

None
text:
This soup is just fantastic!  I usually process the squash and freeze it so I will be able to make this soup on almost a  moment's notice.  After cooking the squash, I strain the cooking stock and freeze it in an ice cube tray and put the cubes in another freezer bag.  When I later thaw and add cream cheese to the previously cooked squash, I add some "ice" cubes and/or half-and-half, heavy cream or just water to thin it out a little.

text:
My new favorite soup!  the addition of the cream cheese is key in this recipe, although after the first time I only use 1/2 to 1 block of light cream cheese and that definitely does the trick.  I've made this recipe a few times, and once I did get a slightly mealy texture...I think it must have been the squash since everything else was the same.  Judging from my experience and a lot of the other reviewers, this soup is pretty versatile and can be altered and varied quite a bit with fab results, just don't forget the cream cheese!!!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/278802.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fabulous!  I would say the best I have tasted so far.  I used leftover squash that I had cubed and roasted in the oven the night before with brown sugar.  I sauted onion and added a clove of minced garlic until tender, then started adding chicken stock, then the left over squash until it was all cooked through.  I pureed in food processor with cream cheese, then just heated it through again right before we ate.   Taking into consideration other comments on the cream cheese, definataly add the cream cheese about 3 or 4 ounces at a time, that way you can get to the richness that you prefer before you have taken it too far.  I added less than half the recipe called for.  Lovely!!

DELICIOUS!  I make this all the time!  It really is so delicious!  If I have the cream cheese, I put it in, but if I don't, I use milk when I blend it. Amazing! I followed all instructions to a T, except I used 1/4 of the cream cheese called for, since we have family members that need to avoid fat where possible.   I also found that 2 squash made 12 cups cubed, maybe I just had large squash. It was a good thing though, because I doubled the recipe and ran out immediately!! For those of us who like spicy foods, of course. I don't recommend that much cayenne for the average person.  I would give this recipe a 6th star, but they won't let me.

LOVED it - my family is watching cholesterol though, so i made a few changes: i didn't have marjoram, so we used a rosemary/garlic spice mix (the kind you can get for dipping bread in!) we used 8 oz. neufchatel cheese instead of cream cheese, and we got it to the consistency we needed (ours was rich and thick thick THICK) by adding skim milk. we topped ours off with a dollop of fat-free sour cream (so cool and creamy against the warm sweet/spicy soup) and had fresh-baked bread on the side.

Unbelievably good! I too baked my squash in the oven first. I used butter instead of margarine, 2 cans of chicken broth and cut the cream cheese in half. text:
Wow! I had to create an account just to comment on this recipe. I have been eating a great butternut squash soup at a restaurant for years, but I think I like this one better! And it's so easy to make! I just halved and microwaved my squash face down for 10 minutes or so until it was easily scooped out. Then I just added the squash, sauteed onion, and other ingredients right into the blender, instead of into a pot. I also added a little extra cayenne pepper just because I like a little extra spice. And less than half the cream cheese, but it was still a very rich and creamy soup. Will be eating this all winter!

text:
This is really good soup. I used about 150g of cream cheese and it was very creamy and delicious. Dh said it could do with a little more cream cheese, but I didn't think so. The cream cheese gives it a slightly sweet, very faint abstract taste that suits it well. I baked the squash with two cloves of garlic. The only problem was, this recipe took ages from start to finish. I made strawberry jam in about half the time. I gave this recipe 4 stars for the taste, though, not on timing as it was my choice to roast the 2 squash I had. I have tasted a better soup at a restaurant that I'm still trying to mimic. Thankyou for the recipe. Even my kids ate it!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is great! I made it directly as instructed the first time but the second time I made a few changes that I think make this outstanding! Instead of peeling and cubing the squash I just baked it with butter at 350 for about 45 min, it was much easier to cut the squash in half (or quarters depending on the size) than to peel and cube! Then I used only 8 oz of cream cheese and a little more water-probably because of my elevation. But these changes were wonderful! It was still creamy and delicious but not too creamy and thick like before, with 16 oz of cheese it tasted mostly like cream cheese, but with 8 it was much more balanced.

1/3 of 8oz of cream cheese.

much more flavorful!!!

text:
Never made squash soup before but someone brought me a ton from their garden and thought I'd give it a try. This is an awesome recipe because you can't hardly mess it up. I've made it with one cream cheese, I've used light cream cheese, I've frozen the squash, I've experimented with the spice amounts (love the cayenne)and all batches have turned out wonderful. Baking the squash first is super easy and more tasty compared to boiling. If you don't have anything against pureed soups, try it!

text:
I have made some modifications to this recipe and it is a regular for my family in the fall.  My children request this soup and it is my daughters favorite.  

I use only about 1/2 of a package of cream cheese rather than 2 whole packages.  I omit the cayenne and black pepper, which is my personal preferance, my husband adds the pepper in his bowl.  This soup freezes well, and when I don't have access to fresh local butternut, I use two bags of frozen squash, although it does result in a thinner soup.  

Thank you so much for this recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this Butternut Squash Soup for our Christmas dinner.  I took the advice of various others:  I cut the squash in in half and put each half in the microwave for 10 minutes then scooped it out.  This proved to be very easy and took much less time.  I also reduced the cream cheese by half, using only one 8 oz container.  I also used 4 cups of chicken broth from a can instead of 3.  Everyone loved it, even the kids ate multiple helpings after they got past the color.  I think the cayenne pepper is very important to this recipe.  It gives it that special something that just makes the soup.  Will make this again and soon!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Don't get me wrong, the taste of this soup is fantastic but it needs a little tweeking.  If you follow the recipe perfectly, you'll find (as did I) that this soup is way, way, way too thick.  If this soup is the only thing you'll have for dinner, then it's okay.  If you plan to use it as an appetizer, add some more chicken broth to get it to the consistency that you'll prefer.  You can also get by using only one cream cheese.  Everyone enjoyed the soup but agreed it was too rich.  Good flavor just too thick!

text:
I halfed this recipe because I had only one squash which yielded about 3 cups.  I didn't have marjoram so I did a Google search and discovered that oregano is a stronger cousin so I used that instead. The only other thing that I added was about two cloves of chopped garlic and about 1/2 tsp. of salt to balance the sweetness.  I used 4 oz. of reduced fat cream cheese and it was just right.  I will make this again since it was super easy and went together quickly since I pre-cooked the squash in the microwave.

text:
As the recipe stands, I thought this soup was only okay. It had a beautiful texture, and a good basic flavor, but wasn't anything special. I took other reviewers' advice and only used half the suggested amount of cream cheese. I tweaked it by adding 1 tsp. of cinnamon for depth of flavor, 1 cup of good grated parmesan, 2/3 cup sour cream, and equal amounts of milk and chicken broth to thin it down to my desired consistency. With these changes I thought it was pretty good, but will continue to play with this recipe until I get it just right.

text:
This soup was a hit at thanksgiving dinner after I made a couple of changes.  The first time I made it I followed the recipe exactly and found it too salty and way to rich with the full amount of cream cheese.  So instead of adding chicken boullion cubes I made the water into chicken stock and only put in 1/4 of the cream cheese called for in the recipe.  I also used light cream cheese.  The result was a yummy creamy soup great for a cold winters day.

text:
Very good soup. I kicked the spices up a notch because I was craving spicy - used black pepper, cayenne, mild curry powder & a pinch of nutmeg. I used 1/2 the cream cheese called for, but still noticed that the soup smelled really... cheesy. Didn't taste too cheesy, but the aroma was affected. I think next time I'll go with heavy cream instead. Getting the warm pulp out of a squash that's been roasted or in the microwave without burning your fingers is hard enough, I am not even going to attempt to peel those suckers raw!

country:
None
text:
This was very good.  I followed the suggestion of other reviewers, and pre-baked the squash.  After sauteeing the onions, I added the boullion cubes, seasonings, and only one cup of water to the pan, then added only one package of non-fat cream cheese, to warm.  Then, I pureed it in the food processor, and returned to the pan.  The pre-baked squash was pureed in the food processor, with the remaining 2 cups of water, then also added to the pan to warm.  Be sure not to boil the mixture after the cream cheese is added, or it will separate.  This is a lovely, rich tasting soup, with very little fat, if you reduce the butter and use fat-free cream cheese.  Yum!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I LOVE this soup, and I don't even like squash!  I did cut the cream cheese in half as suggested by many other posters, and it was plenty.  I like a nice thick puree, so I reserved a little of the liquid before blending and was glad I did;  you can always add it back in if you like yours a little thinner.  I found that my trusty stick blender was WAY easier than the food processor too. I also followed the lead of many other posters and microwaved the squash to make it easier to peel and cube (quarter it and scoop out the seeds, meat side down for 5 minutes).  It has a little kick to it because of the pepper & cayenne, but my guests and I didn't think it was too much.  If you have a sensitive stomach you might want to cut back on them and then taste.  ENJOY!!

text:
I was surprised and pleased by this recipe.  I love squash, but am not a huge fan of butternut squash.  However, this recipe was a definite winner with me.  The soup was creamy but not too rich.  I did have a little difficulty pureeing everything after I cooked it, because I had to use a ladle to transfer the soup to a blender, which was a messy process.  I also added about half the cream cheese, and used low fat to decrease the calories.  It still had fantastic flavor.  One thing I would recommend that really helps cut down on the prep time is if you buy the butternut squash already diced, then just cook it with the chicken broth.  I've found it pre-diced at Trader Joe's.

text:
Changed the prep. a little.  Roasted a large squash and two med. onions with about half a head of garlic until the squash was tender.  Then pureed all in the food processor.  Doubled all the spices and added a 1/4 t. of Allspice and a bay leaf.  Dropped in chunks of one 8oz. pkg. of cream cheese while simmering on the stovetop.  We all LOVED it.  Had some kick, but not enough to knock you over.  Next time might use a hand mixer or a blender to see if I can get it even smoother.

text:
Wow!  Wow!!  Wow!!!  I used one block of cream cheese (1/3 lower fat) and it was wonderful!  My 2 year old got a taste and came running back to me saying, "Mommy, I neeeeed moooore soup."  Go figure, my husband said it was ok, but the rest of us loved it.  I halved the squash, seeded it,  and nuked it for 4 minutes to soften it.  It was much easier to peel and cube then.

text:
Yummy soup for a cool autumn evening... and so easy!I roasted the onions and squash first,intensfied the flavor immensely. No majoram in my cupboard so added powdered ginger and thyme...and only a 1/3 of the cream cheese(low fat). I can't imagine 16 oz of cream cheese in this soup!!! Also made my own stock last month and it made the soup that much better. A GREAT soup, so rich it makes a meal with a green salad and some bread.

text:
Great soup, after a few modifications. Leave out the spices and cream cheese, and roast the squash for better flavout. Instead of the recommended spices, add the following, for a really flavourful, rich soup:

1-1.5 Tbsp Thai Yellow Curry Paste
1 Tbsp. brown sugar
1/2 can coconut milk
1 tsp. Thai Fish sauce
juice of 1 lime

Adjust spice to taste, and enjoy!

text:
I make this rich creamy soup many times each fall & winter since I found it on this website. Last year it was a very impressive first course for our Thanksgiving meal.
I have used half the amount of cream cheese, it is very rich and half the amount is fine.
Really delicious and easy. The only hard part is cutting up the hard squash, but it's worth it.
My sister took a crockpot full to a party and it was empty in no time.
A winner!

text:
I was so dissapointed in the final result of this soup because it really was like baby food in consistency- so much so that we had to throw it out.  And I also cut down on the cream cheese.  Before I added the cream cheese and pureed it,  I kept tasting the broth and thought it was very good, so I anticipated a great soup.  Then it was a huge pain to puree in batches, and we couldn't even eat the final soup!  I might attempt this again, but will not puree.  Also, what made it much easier was buying the pre-packaged cut p butternut squash our supermarket sells.  You just throw it in- no cutting involved.  Anyhow, the broth tastes good, so it is a good base.

text:
What a great way to eat squash!  I love soups in general, but frankly, this was one of the best soups I've ever made!!  My 17 month old loved it which is pretty amazing since I served him cubed butternut squash the day before and he was spitting it out.  As a modification, I cooked the squash in the microwave, only put in 1 tub (8 oz) of light cream cheese (I couldn't imagine putting in 2!), used canned chicken broth and pureed with a hand mixer right in the microwave bowl.  Like others have mentionned, the only time consuming task was peeling and cubing the squash, but it is soooo worth it!

We don't really care too much for squash on its own but I can see this soup becoming a 
weekly "must-have".  I took it to work and everyone raved about it as well. THANKS!!!

I also used my hand blender and pureed the soup right in the pot instead of pouring it into my blender a little at a time because hot liquids expand in a blender once it's turned on.  Less dishes to wash!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I cut the butternut squash in bigger pieces and put in a pot of boiling water for 15 mins approx.  Then drained and cool the squash. Then I peeled the skin off each piece. It may have taken more time but it is hard to cut uncook squash. In the meantime, while the squash was cooling I mixed all the other ingredients in the pot except the cream and butter.  After I added the Cooked squash and the cream cheese and butter I used hand blender and pureed all together. It was the perfect thick soup for a cold winter night!. I added nutmeg and salt & pepper, my husband added salt & pepper. Add more seasoning to your Desiree. I will make it again and share it with friends.

text:
This is my new favourite squash soup. Itâs so much easier and less ingredients than most recipes so it appealed to me. I donât have a blender or immersion blender so I made a few adjustments. I cooked the squash in the microwave. I cut it in half and covered it with plastic wrap and cooked it until it was tender. Check it every 8 minutes. Then I sautÃ©ed the finely chopped onions in the margarine. I used one 8 oz. cream cheese because thatâs all I had in the house. I used a food processor and blended the squash, cream cheese that I cut into small pieces and the onions. Then I whisked in the broth. I also had 4 cups of  vegetable broth to use up so I used that. It made the soup a bit thinner but I donât think the end result was changed just the process.  Very good recipe.

text:
This was a great base recipe! Like the other reviews mention, I roasted the squash after cutting it into 8 pieces for an hour at 350Â°F with a mixture of black pepper, Himalayan salt, freshly minced garlic, and olive oil. It comes right out of the skin with a spoon! Iâm in college, so I donât have a blender or a food processor. I just mashed the hot squash with the cream cheese using a large spoon and incorporated it into the soup after adding the broth and spices. Oh yeah! I used 3 cups of chicken broth instead of the water and chicken bouillon cubes. I also added about a pound of chicken breast tenderloins that I cubed to 1 inch pieces. I put these in with the onions to get them started. Delicious! Sprinkle with some Parmesan cheese when serving. Pairs great with some beer bread.

text:
INCREDIBLE!
Yes; I made a few changes per some suggestions from other reviews. I cut the squash in half length-wise, brushed on some olive oil, then roasted face-down in the oven at 375 for 45 minutes. I think this will really bring out the flavor. I also added minced garlic to the onion, and used a minimal amount of cream cheese.  This recipe is amazing and I will certainly make this over and over.

text:
Delicious & super easy. I roasted the squash first in olive oil, salt & pepper for about 20 min. I think that gave it a deeper flavor. I used half the cream cheese and I still found it super creamy. If I make it again I will actually use more squash (I had about 2 cups leftover from 1 big squash) - it was really rich (which was good) but it could be squashier & still taste fantastic. I think this is one you can definitely play with the amounts to find your perfect squash to creamy ratio.

I used my Vitamix to purÃ©e in small batches the squash along with onions that I sautÃ©d in butter, cooked bacon, and chicken bone broth. I dumped the purÃ©ed soup into a pot. For a spicy kick, I roasted two large seeded jalapeÃ±os and purÃ©es those with some heavy cream and added that to the squash mixture. This was fantastic and really hit the spot for a warm, rich meal on a blustery cold fall day. We made some homemade sourdough bread too that we used to dip in the soup.

text:
This soup turned out pretty good actually. Of course I made it a little different from the recipe after reading other reviews. I brought the precut squash at Walmart to save some time and boiled the chunks in 4 cans of chicken broth. I dumped all the seasonings the recipe called for (I only had Marjoram flakes) plus, 1tsp garlic, 1 T curry powder. I uses a shallot rather than onion since thatâs what I had on hand. I used only 1 8oz cream cheese and added 1 c unsweetened coconut milk, 1/2 c half n half. I emulsified the squash but did leave small chunks since my hubby needs texture. I will make this again.

text:
I used an organic squash, and added a little bit of Tumeric. The color was slightly paler than the picture, but it tasted fantastic.  I ended up baking a squash for an hour, letting it cool, peeled the skin and put chunks into a large pot, then added all ingredients in the pot, and used a hand blender to blend it all, right in the pot as I heated it!  Easy!

text:
was great.  did as others suggested by putting it in the oven for about an hour. Though i still feel like next time ill purchase them already cut. worth the extra money for me. after i cubed them i used some of the onions and chopped 4 garlic cloves ( made  recipe servings  for 18) and mixed it together with the squash with some EVOO and put it back in oven for 10 min. i then transferred to pot and only added in 2 medium sweet potatoes and an apple. The potatoes  gave it a bit of a creamy texture . I used absolutely ZERO dairy. No cream cheese, no cream, no nothing.  It was amazing! try it without the dairy. YUM!

text:
This was delicious!!! I made it a bit easier though by baking a large while squash first in the oven at 375 for about 75 minutes. Then when it cooled slightly, I cut it open, took out the seeds, and then scooped out the squash. I then added 6 cups of the cooked squash with the cream cheese and blended with a mixer. After that, I added it to the onion,  butter mixture and stirred in the rest the ingredients. Super easy and super yummy!!

text:
Iâve made this soup recipe several times.  The first time I made it, I followed the recipe to a T.  Itâs good as is but after adding a few other ingredients it takes it over the top.  I like to add a sweet potato to it sometimes if the squash is more yellow than orange..itâs a visual thing more than anything else.  I add a little poultry seasoning or thyme, a few shakes of Worcestershire, couple shakes fish sauce (I know it sounds gross but you canât taste fish unless you overdo it), and a few shakes of nutmeg.  I actually put this additional concoction in many of my stews and chowders and it never disappoints.  Just start really small and adjust to taste (after youâve blended the original recipe so you can get an accurate idea of what the complete package tastes like and gauge it from there).  It creates an added umami profile you never knew you needed until you try it.  This soup is so good my daughter asks for it as part of her birthday dinner every year.  Also..throw a few bacon bits or pancetta on top and it becomes the pinnacle of greatness..because ya know..itâs bacon.

Quick & easy:  I sautÃ©ed everything in a pot while squash was in oven roasting.  When cooled, I put cooked squash pieces in the pot and mashed with a potato masher.  Then added cream cheese and again mashed with potato masher.   Done! One pot soup, easy clean up!

Display Name:
Marie Sicre

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4811378.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'll tell you what is missing from this recipe to give it ALL STARS... as I have been making it for over 21 years when it was published in a Kraft recipe booklet (for the cream cheese that is used).   To take this recipe over the top as originally written you puree roasted red pepper in a food processor and dollop it onto the finished soup.  Using a toothpick you can swizzle and make elegant designs with the pepper and then add chopped basil.  I also love adding thyme while the squash is simmering.  Taste as you go along.  This has been my winter Squash soup for over 20 years and you can tweak it to your liking.....but honestly, garnishing this with the pureed roasted red pepper and  chopped basil as originally written by Kraft truly makes this  eye candy, and a WOW for your friends and family

5

text:
Thought it was delicious and easy to make!
My modifications:
I quartered the squash and microwaved face down for 8 minutes before peeling.
Thought it was too salty with 4 cubes, so added only 3 (same amount of water).
Added 1 T fresh minced garlic to onions.
Omitted the marjoram (only bc I didn't have it).
Used 4 oz of cream cheese.
Still creamy, smooth and amazing!!!

text:
This is my go-to butternut squash soup!  Sometimes I use sour cream instead of cream cheese and it's just as good but with fewer calories.  I've also served with pumpkin seeds which gave it a wonderful crunchy texture.  Lately I've only been blending just a few scoops of the squash so there are still delightful chunks of squash left to chew on.  I've also made it with a potato added it and that was a nice addition.

text:
Found the secret missing ingredient!! More on that below. This was delicious and easy! :) I followed the recommendation of many other reviewers and baked the squash first (halved and put face-down on a cookie sheet, 375 for 50 minutes), cut up an onion, and used 5 c. chicken broth instead of bouillon and water. Cut the cream cheese in half to one block.

GINGER! I added the spices as it called for, which was yummy, but a teaspoon of ginger added such a rich, delicious fullness to it that totally complemented the other flavors already present. I added a dollop of sour cream once it was in my bowl. Sooooo good! I will make this again and again.

Made this dairy-free using room temperature coconut butter (not coconut oil, but the butter made from the whole coconut flesh), and tahini at a 4:1 oz ratio. It turned out amazing!! And because the coconut butter was room temp, the soup didn't require reheating after pureeing it. I just stirred it thoroughly in the still warm sauce pan. Delish and simple recipe!

userID:
2432596
Display Name:
rhiaus
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my daughter's favourite soup. She takes it to school for lunch throughout the fall and winter months. I replace the water and chicken boullion with vegetable broth. I also roast the squash in the oven first. (Cut in half,  vegetable side down in about a 1/2 inch of water at about 375 degrees for 40 mins)  With 20 mins left in roasting the squash, I put in 2 peeled, cored and quartered MacIntosh apples. Once the squash is roasted (fork should easily pierce the skin), I remove the skins and throw the squash along with the apples in the pot with the rest of the simmering soup base. At the very end I use the hand blender to smooth out the lumps. This is so delicious. I have served it as an appetizer for Christmas dinner as well. As a helpful hint - I once bought frozen cubed squash thinking I was saving time. DO NOT do this, it really lacked flavour. It was the only time my daughter did not finish the batch. There is a wonderful taste that comes from the roasted squash.

Display Name:
Bettylovestocook!
isPro:

followersCount:
0

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/198543.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is one of the best soups I have ever made; DELICIOUS!  I cooked a med sized squash in the crock pot, and peeled it.  I cooked 1/4 of a  onion chopped and 2 chopped celery stocks in 1 T butter. I added 1 diced clove garlic at the end and then  I added 2 C water and 2 t chicken base, a couple of pinches  of cayenne, and of black pepper and added squash.  Boil for a short time, and then blend with immersion blender.  I then stirred in 4 oz of cream cheese, cooked until melted, and then used immersion blender again.  Really AMAZING!!  MY husband loved it and he does not like squash!

text:
This is one of my favorite Fall recipes, but I do tweak it quite a bit. First, I roast the squash. I also add a chopped, peeled apple or two and cut the cream cheese quantity in half. I use vegetable broth instead of water. 
My son made this recently and followed the recipe precisely, and we all agreed that it was much, much too rich (too much cream cheese) and not "squashy" enough.

Loved this soup! I roasted the squash with some olive oil and minced garlic first, then blended it together with the rest of the ingredients. I opted out of the cream cheese and instead substituted 2 cups water and 1 cup half & half instead of 3 cups water. I added a chipotle pepper and a bit more Cayenne pepper. text:
I followed the recipe essentially as written. I did start the squash in the oven to roast for 45 min but then ended up cutting it up and cooking it in my Instant Pot. It did help giving it a start in the oven. While it was hot to touch, it made peeling it easier. Next time I will cook it in the Instant Pot entirely and then make it into soup.

But I digress... following the recipe as written except for only adding one brick of cream cheese instead of two. I also added some apple cider, based upon a previous reviewer's suggestion. This made it good but it seemed bland. I ended up adding some powdered ginger and then some french seasoning from Penzey's. That took it to a new level, can't wait to have it for lunch tomorrow! Thanks for the recipe!

I added a carrot, chopped, and 1 stalk of celery, sliced with the onions when I sauteed them after seeing another butternut soup recipe.  I also used only 1 pkg of cream cheese as someone else had suggested.  It was very creamy with that one and I think would have been too rich with 2 pkgs.    I also roasted the squash pieces with some smashed garlic cloves as another person suggested.  Then everything went into the crock pot and simmered for about 3 hours.  Delicious!  I will definitely make this again.

text:
WOW!  This was delicious!  The only change I made was I cut the squash in half (lengthwise) and placed each half cut side down on a buttered cookie sheet and then baked it for 40 min in the oven at 375 degrees.  This really brought out the flavor and made it simple to scoop away from the skin.  I then followed the receipe as instructed.  Also I only used 1/2 the suggested cream cheese - for my family that was perfect. Yum!

My husband gave it 5 stars, I gave it 4.  I used one package of lower fat cream cheese.  I think two packages would have lost the flavor of the butternut squash.  It was rich and creamy with just the one pkg.  I also used 4 cups of chicken broth instead of the water and bouillon.  It was easier than trying to pick the pieces of wrapper off the bouillon that always sticks! :)

text:
I made this twice now and my family loves it. The first time, I made it just like the recipe which was still pretty good. The second time, I changed it up. I used chicken stock instead of bouillon. I used rosemary and parsley instead of marjoram and cayenne pepper but I kept the black pepper. I caramelized the onions which added to the sweetness of the butternut squash. I also added a little bit of maple smoked bacon to add more flavor to complement the squash. My family inhaled the second batch. I had no leftovers to put into the fridge.

Heat until warm and purÃ©e small portions in blender, return to pot and heat to serving temperature. I did not use any of the cream cheese...it was amazing without the extra fat.

It was really very easy to make and quite tasty. I followed suggestions from a lot of the other reviewers by roasting the squash ahead of time to make it easier to cut and peel and shorten the cooking time. I only added 1 package of cream cheese, used chicken stock instead of water, and added a little red curry powder.  The results were fantastic, my husband who doesn't like squash or curry really liked it! I will for sure make this again to use up garden squash.

text:
I toss it in a regular oven for an hour until fork tender. Peel comes right off and it's easy to cut- and then your soup is done lickety-split too. 

Like others I've kinda combined other recipes in to this one. I sautÃ©e carrot celery and onion, add (homemade but  I've used low sodium broth too) chicken stock, sweet potato or pumpkin purÃ©e (I had neither on hand this time so I baked a sweet potato along with the squash- also unpeeled and voila!). I add a few globs of cream cheese, applesauce, honey, cinnamon and for a little kick since I can't do curry I add ginger. Salt and pepper to taste. I add roasted veggies to sautÃ©ed veggies in the stock pot, simmer a bit and use my immersion blender.

Very easy and delicious recipe! I usually love cream cheese but this recipe does call for a lot. I halved the amount as suggested and it was plenty. I also used reduced sodium chicken broth. I love spice but this was a bit too spicy for my 9 and 5 year old. So I'll probably cut the amount of cayenne next time. Added Crema Mexicana as a garnish which went very well with this soup. 
I was also able to add the entire mixture to the blender at once with no issues.
I think grilled ham and cheese would go great with this soup!

text:
Great recipe, very rich and creamy. My husband loves the little kick the spices give it. To cook my butternut squash, I cut it in half lengthwise, turn the halves face-down in a glass baking dish, fill the dish with about an inch of water, and bake in the oven at 375 for about 40 minutes. After it cools a little, you can just scoop the butternut squash out.

Love this recipe. I've made it a few times now, first time I followed a reviewer's suggestion and added half the cream cheese but everything else the same. Turned out great. This last time I was not feeling like peeling and cubing the butternut squash, so I cut in half and roasted in the oven, until it was tender. And, I left the cream cheese out to cut some calories. Still turned out delicious and the cauliflower addition made it a more "meatier" soup.

text:
This was my first time cooking with butternut squash.  This was a good beginning.  I read many reviews before making it.  I roasted my squash in the oven, salted with olive oil.  I sauteed my onions in part butter and part coconut oil. Like many I only used one package of cream cheese.  I put in two 32 oz cartons of chicken broth.  Maybe that' why mine didn't come out too thick.  It probably could have been a little thicker.  So next time I'll use slightly less chicken broth, but definitely more than the 5 cups of broth that I was going to use per one reviewer's suggestion. I didn't have marjoram. So I used oregano and thyme as one reviewer did.  I used one-fourth teaspoon of cayenne instead of the one-eighth called for and it wasn't too spicy.  I will definitely make this again.

Made on December 10/15 used 2 pkg. frozen squash thawed, roast for 20minutes with olive oil . SautÃ© onions and minced garlic, then add one sliced apple then ad squash, chicken broth (4cups) and spices including 2Tbsp. Brown sugar, 1 tsp nutmeg.  Simmer for 1 hour then drop 1pkg cream cheese to soften for few minutes, when tender cool abit then put in small batches into nutribullet. YUMMY!!!! Made again September 26/18,  soooo good! Next time only 1/8 cayenne pepper not 1/4 tsp. add two apples and roast squash longer 40 minutes on 350 or if using fresh cut into quarters drizzle with EVOO and roast at 375 for 45-60 minutes til tender and easy to scoop, 1-2 tsp minced garlic also try a little cinnamon and maybe cloves or allspice instead of cayenne

This came out really delicious! I added 3/4 head of cauliflower, and only 3/4 of 1 block of cream cheese. Next time I would only use about 1/2 block, it was on the rich side for me.  (I feel like 2 whole blocks would make it inedible!) I took the advice of others and roasted the squash in the oven for 45 minutes. I cooked the cauliflower in the spiced broth for about 15 minutes, then added the squash and simmered for another 10. 
Sprinkled some fresh mint leaves on top and some whole wheat naan on the side for dipping. Yummy!

country:

text:
Once you make this soup there won't be a need for another roasted butternut squash soup recipe; this is hands down the best!  I tweek mine ever so slightly.  I don't put the cream cheese in mine.  Instead I put heavy cream in the blender because it is the ideal consistency in about 30 seconds.  I might add a bit more stock depending on how much butternut squash I added because I usually add a bit more to get a thicker soup.  I put a big dollop of heavy cream on the top of the soup with a sprinkle of the course red sea salt and some homemade croutons (sourdough bread, butter, olive oil and parmesan cheese and kosher salt).  I use the biggest stock pan I have and we seldom have any leftovers.  The roasted butternut squash makes this recipe a real winner!

This is delicious - of course a couple of differences.  I did roast the squash along with an onion and a couple pieces of garlic at 375 degrees for 40 minutes as others mentioned. text:
Absolutely will make this again. Just delicious. I made 1.5 of this recipe, used a half cup more of the substituted chicken broth (to use up 3 full cans instead of 2.5) in addition to the bullion, not in place of, and used the two cream cheese as called for in the original recipe (not 1.5). I had no problem cutting up the squash-cut it in rings of about 1.5" wide, then peeled it around like you would an apple, then chopped. It was very flavorful and just a smidge on the salty side and not as thick as the picture, which was fine. Next time I will just double the recipe and use only half of the bullion. Still, first attempt was a smash hit! I almost put cubed ham in it, but wanted to taste the recipe as is, so I put the ham on our salads instead-paired very well with the soup. So good.

country:
None
text:
Tweaked the recipe (for my own tastes)
- Skinned the squash before roasting it per SLJ6's review as I used most of their tweaks as well, made for easier handling.
- Cubed the squash instead of quartering it.
- Tripled the garlic, we love garlic.
- 6 cups equals approx 1 squash FYI
- Substituted Veggie broth for Chicken
- Sauted the onions in butter instead of margarine
- Halved the cream cheese

Great soup! Warm, comforting, and freezes wonderfully. Vegetarian family loved it and meatatarian DBF tolerated it. Very heavy and filling, and I can eat a lot so with a salad could be a meal in and of itself.

Display Name:
Amanda Koss
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2723497.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this recipie for years and I have finally perfected it!!! I made a few tweaks with trial and error over the years but this soup is amazing if you do the following:

Use 3 butternut squash, halved and roasted in the oven with crushed garlic and evoo at 350 until soft. Let cool and refrigerate over night only because I'm lazy.

Sautee 1/4c onion, add squash, 1 large peeled Granny Smith Apple and 4c water. Boil, then purÃ©e with immersion blender.  I get about 10-12c squash out of the 3 I use. Add 5 bullion cubes, add more water as I go to desired consistency. Add 1 brick of cream cheese, 1tbs marojam, 1tsp cyanne, fresh pepper and some fresh salt. Let simmer stirring occasionally for an hour to marry the flavors.

Roast the squash seeds in olive oil, a dash of salt and some lowerys seasoning salt... Just a smudge! Use this to top the soup!!! Soooooo good! 

Serve with crusty bread and cyanne powder. Mind blown!

text:
For the most part, we loved this soup. I just now read the past review suggesting putting the butternut squash in the oven to help with the peeling process. I highly recommend that. I had a very hard time peeling that thing! 

The soup had fantastic flavor. Our only complaint was that it was pretty rich. I'm not sure how to remedy that problem, because, frankly, rich isn't always a bad thing. However, we all left a little hungry because we didn't eat as much as we might have if it wasn't so rich. 

With that being said, I would still recommend making this soup for a nice cool Autumn day.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I wanted a lower fat option and also one that was dairy free. So I used a DF butter substitute and left out the bullion, water, and cream cheese. Instead I used almond milk and a little more seasoning. (More cayenne, salt, pepper, garlic, & parsley). My little ones didn't like it, but the older kids and adults loved it! (It was a bit on the spicy side).  Also, I roasted the squash, then scooped out the cooked meat. The onions I sauteed with all the seasoning, then blended it all together with the almond milk in batches. Finally, I let it simmer while making the rest of the meal. Very yummy!

userID:
11085623
Display Name:
steelydawn
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first time making butternut squash soup. Loved this soup! Thank you for the recipe and reviews to help me twig it the way I know I would like it. I sprayed a tinfoil lined pan with olive oil and roasted a small butternut squash (open side down/scoop out the seeds)and 2 cloves of garlic (put them under the hole where the seeds were) at 350 degrees for 45 min. Let it cool down. While it was cooling I sauteed 2T butter with finely chopped onion until soft. I added 1C of the chicken stock. I scooped out the squash with an icecream scoop and added it to the pot along with 2 more cups of the chicken stock, a pinch of  five spice (I didn't have cloves so this worked), black pepper to taste. Then I put it all in the blender and mixed it up.I heated it back up in the pot, then added a dollup of sour cream and mixed it in.(I did not use any cream cheese) I spooned it into bowls and grated parmesan cheese in the middle and added a pinch of parsley flakes.  Mmmm so good! Makes 4-5 bowls

text:
i only used 1/2 the cream cheese and still thought it was too...cream cheese tasting for me. but the squash flavor was amazing. my squash was a little over 2 lbs - i cut it in 1/2 , drizzled olive oil, salt, and pepper, and baked in over at 350 for 30 minutes, then preceded with the recipe as written. the hardest part was getting the skin off of it. next time i may skin before baking. once everything was sauteed together in the pan and just before blending with cream cheese, i tasted the squash and it was AMAZING. it was so good i almost didn't want to make it into soup! i'd like to try a slightly healthier/less rich version that didn't involve cream cheese or at least not so much of it...

I used to make a version of this when I lived in the BAsque country in Spain.  Instead of onions, I used a couple of chopped leeks, sauteed until soft, then added cubes of squash or pumpkin and the chicken stock.  Let it cook until soft, throw in ONE, not two lower fat cream cheese packages and used an immersion blender to make a smooth, rich, almost puree-like soup.

text:
This soup is a stand by for me with a couple of changes. I am allergic to dairy so I use coconut milk instead of cheese. I also add 1 T of fresh ginger and a few red pepper flakes. It is one of my favorites. I cook my squash as (in the skin) in the microwave for  about 15 minutes depending on size. Then I cut it, deseed it, and scoop out the squash with a spoon. This is so much easier that trying to peel and cut up raw.

text:
I make this soup all the time. It's always a hit and freezes well. I like to serve it with fish or pork. I have tried this recipe as is and it was great. After a few times I started adding a roasted red pepper as well as roasting the squash. It brings out the the flavours. As far as the cream cheese, it really dose ad a great dimension but the things that are bad for us always do. The soup stands on its own without it but I think the cream cheese is worth the calories, after all it's a starter not a meal.

text:
I am putting 4 vs 5 stars because I slightly altered the recipe. My butternut squash was 4 cups worth so I decided to reduce the quantities accordingly. I also had to substitute oregano because I didn't have the marjoram on hand (its in the same family just a little stronger so reduced amount to 1/4 tsp). I also used reduced fat cream cheese and instead of cayenne pepper I had a smokey hot pepper meade that I thought would add good flavor instead. Then I tried it and thought it still needed something. I added some cooked broccoli florets and cubeds some baked chicken. Yep thats what it needed to make it fabulous in my book and I shall continue to do so going forward. :) -Thanks for the recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I didn't read the comments of others to first roast the squash until after I had it cubed.  So I went with the original recipe, except I used butter instead of margarine.  Also, I didn't have marjoram, so I substituted 1 tsp coriander, 1 Tbsp curry powder, and 1/2 tsp nutmeg.  I also used only one (8 oz.) package cream cheese instead of 2 as the recipe called for.  It was very tasty!  Although I think next time I will try only 4 oz. cream cheese.  This recipe is simple, forgiving, and can easily be tweeked and experimented with to suite personal taste.

Delicious and super easy to make!  Only a few modifications - I used an acorn squash instead of a butternut (it's what I had on hand), and roasted it in a 350 oven - cut side down - on a baking sheet for 45 minutes.  I increased the cayenne pepper to 1/4 t. and added a dash of nutmeg.

text:
I followed some advice and halved the squash, brushed with olive oil, salt, pepper and garlic and baked at 400 for 30 minutes.  Much easier to peel...We like things on the spicy side, so I doubled the cayenne pepper, added a dash of nutmeg, a tsp of brown sugar, 2 chopped potatoes, and a chopped apple; boiled for 20 minutes then added the squash and boiled for another 10 minutes.  The cream cheese added a wonderful flavor.  As in previous reviews, I only used one 8 oz brick of cream cheese.  Absolutely delicious!

text:
Because this soup is rather "bland" in the sense that there isn't a mix of vegetables or beans in it, I choose to serve it over white rice. It is an easy way of making it a hearty soup :)

I have had butternut squash soup before that was MUCH sweeter and better tasting. While the consistency was great, the taste wasn't on par for me. I added brown sugar and cinnamon to help compensate for the lack of taste but it still wasn't the same...still searching for a good butternut squash soup recipe :(

Oh, and one pack of cream cheese is plenty! Richness was fine.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe. 
I followed some of the changes and added my own and my boyfriend said it is his all time favorite soup and he doesn't even like butternut squash. 

First, I cut two butternut squash in half, put some EVOO and salt/pepper on them and cut side down roasted them at 375 for 45 min. 

Towards the end of the squash cooking time, I sautÃ©ed the onions in the butter with two cloves of garlic until translucent. 

I used only two chicken bouillon cubes, added the rest of the ingredients to the pot, including the scooped out squash. Oh and I almost forgot, I added one chopped up and peeled apple to the pot. 

Added that all to a blender and since I only had half a block of cream cheese, used that. 
Tasted PHENOMENAL. 
I topped each bowl with some fresh steamed corn since I had a bunch and wanted to use it and some chopped chives. 

Delish.

text:
This is a great start for butternut squash soup.  I roasted the squash until it was tender (roasting adds much more flavor than boiling it and makes it much easier to cut and peel).  I used oregano instead of marjoram just because I didn't have the marjoram and it was a good substitute.  I used one package of cream cheese and thought it was very creamy.  My husband (who HATES all types of squash) was even impressed by this recipe.  If you have an immersion blender, use it!  Much easier and faster.

text:
This recipe is good, but I think it calls for too much cream cheese.  When I was in the final stages of prep, I was thinking, wow, I LOVE creamy things - I mean I make my morning coffee as a heavy whip misto - but I thought I'd start small with half the amount of cream cheese - and it was still very heavy.  When I make again, I think I will do with 1/4 the amount.  I have to imagine that this is a typo, because I feel like this recipe is for butternut squash flavored cream cheese.  

Other than this - the recipe is quite fantastic!  I used real butter, add some garlic and extra cayenne, and also added salt as I use homemade stock that does not have any.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great Recipe! Thank you so much!
This was easy, quick and delicious.  Like so many others, I did alter the recipe some based on the many reviews I read.  The alterations I made that I would do again: Add butter instead of margarine, buy pre pealed and precut fresh squash then boil in store bought chicken broth, add cinnamon, nutmeg about 1/8 cup of fresh parsley and doubled the cayenne for a little extra kick!  Flavor was amazing! Didt not need ANY salt.. love that!

What I would do different... I had already altered the cream cheese down to 1/2  of one pack. If I had to do it again, I would cut it down to 1/4 pack or none. I recommend blending everything and trying it without the cream cheese and perhaps adding it to taste. You may end up with two packs if that is your preference, or you may think 1/2 a pack is perfect, or none at all may suit you.  Just give yourself the chance to make the choice before going all in!

5

text:
Yum!  

The only 2 changes to this recipe were as follows:
1. I used just 1 pkg of cream cheese (1 pkg seemed to be plenty, and I used 1/3 less fat).
2. I baked my butternut squash whole (with a few fork pokes) at 400 for 1 hr and 20 mins.  I used a rather large squash, so if you decide to bake yours, you should adjust your baking time accordingly.

This will definitely be on my list of favorites.  Thanks for sharing!

userID:
7286984
Display Name:
IamMe
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
35
favoritesCount:
214
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
So delicious it almost tastes like a dessert. And it is really filling. All I had was a bowl of salad and a bowl of soup and I was completely satisfied, and I'm training for a marathon so I'm always really hungry!

I tried to make this recipe exactly as it is, except that I did roast the squash ahead of time because it was a beast just to cut in half, and I scaled down some of the measurements because I was just going to use half of a squash.

I brushed on olive oil and rosemary on the faces of the cut-in-half squash, baked them face-down for 1 hour on 375, then scooped out the seeds, peeled them with a potato peeler, and cubed. Meanwhile, I was leaving the cream cheese out to soften. By this point the squash was already really mushy, but I went ahead and boiled it with the onions and other spices. Since the squash had already baked an hour in the oven, it was still really hot, so after I pureed everything in the blender, I just put it in bowls and served. My mother-in-law wanted her bowl heated, but she's the kind who likes things to be scalding. I ate a salad first and my soup was still a good temperature when I moved on to it.

For timing, I put the squash in the oven at 4:15, took out at 5:15, and let them cool, then started peeling at 5:30, did everything else and was ready to serve it by just a little after 6.

First time ever trying butternut squash and wow did this recipe deliver.  The little bit of cayenne really hit the spot, even my 8 year old boy loved it.. we had it with garlic bread. The next day,(today)off the bus, the kids ate it cold and used it as a kind of dip for a sandwich before church. Definitely this recipe will now be on regular rotation. One extra is that we roasted the squash in the oven beforehand, if you do this be prepared for extra time for it. We also doubled the cream cheese, but since we aren't an exact measurement family we probably used more squash also. Yummy!

text:
Good recipe. Like others I only used half the amount of cream cheese, any more and you;d run the risk of this being squash-fondue. I'd also suggest being careful the water does not boil off and making sure there is enough liquids when you begin blending, or else it comes out too thick. I also doubled the amount of cayenne pepper, because I like the added kick.

text:
Just made this and love it! I read the reviews and made some minor adjustments. First, I made 3 times as much so I can freeze some for later. I also used veggie broth instead of chicken and added about 1/2 cup half and half to make it a creamier texture. Also added about a tablespoon of brown sugar. At first I thought it wouldn't be thick or creamy enough, until I put it in the blender, then it came out perfect! Yum.

This soup is SOOOOO good.  I have been making it for years and am finally leaving a review. userID:
11416374
Display Name:
ironmaiden1
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
29
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677174.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I made this tonight to use up a butternut squash that came in our weekly box of organic veggies. We did make a few modifications to the recipe. We cut the squash in half, seasoned with salt and pepper, rubbed with a little olive oil and roasted it, cut side down, in a 375 degree oven for 45 minutes.  Since there was no marjoram or cayenne pepper in the pantry, we subbed in a tiny bit of hot chilli powder for heat and flavor. Also, we cut down the bouillon to two cubes as ours is not sodium-free and it seemed that 4 cubes would make the soup too salty. It tasted beautifully rich as it was so we decided not to add any cream cheese, which cut down the fat.  We did thin the soup with some 2% milk before serving as the texture was a little thick - everyone in the family loved it. Great recipe - will definitely make again, especially in the wintertime!

text:
This tasted great but it was a pain to make.  Peeling a raw butternut squash is just not a great idea, so I boiled it whole and then peeled it and chopped it, then added it to the onions and water.  I ended up having to add at least double the water and bouillon because the mixture was too thick for me to puree.  As a final product, the soup was very good, but it's not fun to make and the broth amount in the ingredients needs to be doubled, or the squash and cream cheese halved.

text:
If youre trying to be a little bit healthier when making this just omit the cream cheese and milk all together and add about 3 cups of chicken broth, this is for six servings. I swear it pretty much taste identical just a few hundred calories less, and you might prefer not to use as much salt bc there's usually salt in the broth. Hope this helped!

text:
I loved this soup and so did my family. I did make some changes after reading some of the reviews.  I used 2 tablespoons of butter I don't like margarine, 3/4 of the cream cheese ( I thought 2 pkg was too much)and I did not use chicken bouillon instead I used 32oz of chicken broth from the box or you can use the cans. I peeled the butternut cut in pieces and put in the oven in a cookie sheet to roast. You can adjust the consistency of your soup by adding water or you can add half and half. Since I did not use 2 packages of cream cheese I did add some half and half. If your soup looks great and taste wonderful then you made a delicious soup. Very good on these cold days. :)

text:
Thanks for sharing such a great recipe! Per reviews, I roasted the squash (and garlic) first, to make the squash easier to peel. The only substitutions I made were: bacon fat instead of margarine for sauteing the onion and plain yogurt instead of cream cheese (because I had it already). 

We had mixed reviews over this in our house... I loved it. It has a gorgeous color, a smooth texture, and an uncomplicated flavor with a bit of a kick. This is quite a spicy soup. It was too 'hot' for my three year old & I ended up making something else for her. Next time, I'll keep that in mind. My squash-hating husband didn't like it, but said I should make this at Thanksgiving (though I'm guessing he meant so he'd only have to eat it once a year! *laugh*).

text:
This recipe is amazing. I've made it many times and EVERYONE asks for the recipe. I roast the squash face-down in a 350 degree oven until it's soft enough to be poked with a fork. Then I let it cook and peel. It's much easier this way and the flavor is more intense! I also add a few chopped cloves of garlic when sautÃ©ing the onions, double all the spices, and use only 1 package cream cheese. This is a winner every time!

text:
First time to even eat butternut squash soup.  Loved it!  Sweet and hearty with a slight bite.  I did take the advice of many and went with half the cream cheese.  It was almost too rich with 1 package, I can't imagine 2 packages.  Edit/add: After making this multiple times now, I think the key is making sure you have enough liquid to start, and to make sure you catch it at the right time.  You want to boil the squash until it's breaking down, but not turning into a paste.

None
text:
Serve with hot Parmesan rolls or garlic bread sticks (homemade of course)
8oz of cream cheese is PLENTY! 4C chicken stock is just right. Can add some mashed potato flakes if soup is too thin. (Don't over do it..it takes a minute for the potato to absorb the moisture) Use a stick blender to puree right in the pot. (No burned fingers or lid exploding like in blender) Puree is a must for creamy texture. You can substitute any kind of winter squash or pumpkin

text:
I have made this twice.  Both were amazing.  Second time was easier because I simply baked the squash (cut open, remove seeds and place flesh-side down on aluminum foiled pan) for an hour.  I sauteed onion, boiled the water then combined all with the squash and seasonings.   I pureed with little hand-held blender.   So easy!  The flavor is incredible; I added heavy cream because I am out of cream cheese.

This turned out WAY too thick for our tastes.  Definitely use half or less of the cream cheese.

UPDATE: I decided to give it another try and I made it according to the suggestions that @SLJ6 gave in their review.  It helped, but the soup still ended up being meh. I've seen another recipe for a butternut soup with crab meat, and I think that might give this soup the counterpoint of taste that it needs to be really good.

I have never made butternut squash soup before, but had a squash sitting around, so I decided to give it a whirl.  I was not terribly impressed while eating it...until I looked around online and found that some people add balsamic vinegar to theirs.  So I put a dash in my bowl and a miracle occurred!

In short - balsamic vinegar will take this soup from okay to great!

text:
I HATE squash and last year our pastor's wife gave me a sample of the soup.  I did not have the heart to tell her I would not eat it because I hate squash so I took it and put it in my freezer with no plans to eat it.  Then one day, out of groceries and needing a lunch for work, I packed it.  I heated it up at lunch making faces at the soup and then tasted it.  It was SOOOOOO YUMMY!!!!  This seriously is now one of my all time favorite soups and I HATE SQUASH!!!  I only use 1 block of reduced fat cream cheese and 3 TBL of butter instead of the margarine but it turns out perfect every time!!!  Highly recommend this recipe!!!!
