city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
What a nice comforting soup for a day when our high temperature was 10.  I did change the method while keeping the ingredients the same.  Having never worked with butternut squash before, I took some other reviewers' recommendations and roasted it first.  Then I put the squash and cooked onion with some of the broth into the blender.  I put all of the blended squash in my slow cooker and added 1/2 the cream cheese.  The cheese melted right in, and I let the soup cook on low for about 6 hours.  It was fabulous - rich and creamy and delicious.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674165.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup for my best friend's birthday dinner and it was delicious! The best tips I picked up on this website were to cook the squash, halves face down, in a cake pan with an inch of water at 350 for 1 hour. I then used an ice cream scooper to scoop the squash out and added it to the blender with the cream cheese and chicken broth. I was already sauteing the onion in butter in a saucepan and so it was easy to puree the squash mixture in the blender and then pour it into the pot with the onions and heat through. This reminded me of a soup I used to order at Wolfgang Puck! I highly recommend this one on a cold fall night!

text:
My husband and I don't particularly like squash or soup but oh my, this was delicious.  This recipe is one of the best I've tried from this site.  I used kabocha squash, which has a milder flavor than butternut and is supposed to be excellent for soup.  I roasted the squash before finding this recipe so I didn't follow the recipe exactly.  I added the frozen pureed squash and let it simmer until it thawed.  I whipped the cream cheese on its own and then whisked it into the soup.  I also used veggie bullion to make it vegetarian.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great soup!  I like things easy, so I pealed and cubed a butternut squash put it in a large (glass) pot added a small chopped onion with a couple of cloves of crushed garlic.  Almost covered with some chicken stock, then into the microwave until the squash is tender (about 12 minutes).  I then added the spices, a little brown sugar about 4 oz. of cream cheese and a little half & half then hit it with my immersion blender until smooth.  It was done in no time and to rave reviews.

I would give this recipe five stars, but I changed it slightly, so I can't give it a true review. I also roasted the squash first as others had. I added to much onion but this dish still came out rather good. I think it could almost go without the onion and bacon. My daughter loved it and ate most of it which is impressive because she is 2 years old and usually hates stuff like this. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
FANTASTIC! Used two butternuts from my garden... Like many others, I roasted the squash in the oven for about 45 mins at 350.  I ran out of time, and stored the cooked squash overnight in the fridge. The next day, I sauteed the onions in a dutch oven then put them in a large bowl with the squash and all its juices, and the bouillon (I used Emeril's, as I love it). I used a hand blender to puree. I then added only ONE package of whipped cream cheese. I returned everything to the dutch oven and seasoned with black pepper and a few grates of fresh nutmeg. Did not use cayenne - personal preference. It was rich, thick and delish - loved by all, and reheated beautifully. Thanks for this recipe - I will make this many, many times in the days ahead!

FANTASTIC!!!  But I docked it a star because as almost every other reviewer noted it calls for entirely too much cream cheese... I just did one brick.  Pre-Roasted the squash as others did and this made it so much easier to peel and slice.  Made with vegetable base and needed more liquids, but I think my squash was more than 6 cups (it was around 6 pounds).  Tried to "cheat" and just use a hand mixer in the pot, but that wasn't cutting it so I did have to blend in batches as directed which was somewhat labor intensive and MESSY.  Will definitely make again and experiment with making it further ahead of time, and even freezing it.  My mom suggested tweaking it with curry, which would be a very nice acompaniment to an Indian meal.  Next time I'll serve it with a swirl of sour cream or creme fraische and drops of herbed oil like they do at fancy restaurants =)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great soup to use up my abundance of garden butternut squash!  I roasted the squash with olive oil as others did and I feel this adds greatly to the soups flavor.  I added 3 cloves of garlic in with the onions and a couple stalks of celery.  I had no marjoram, so I substituted sage, which adds a surprisingly good taste.  Left out the cayenne altogether. I did as others and used 3/4 of a pack of cream cheese (1/3 fat).  As the squash was well roasted, it fell apart in the cooking process, so I did not puree it, so it had more texture.  As a vegetarian I also used vegi broth.  Next day the flavors melded wonderfully when we had it as leftovers.  This is a keeper.

text:
SOOOO Good!  I experimented with this soup with my mom and my husband and we all indulged in just 3/4 cup each and it was not only delicious but was very rich and filling!  We all kept rolling it around in our mouths and commenting on the flavors.  The red pepper leaves a slight spice in the back of your throat, but it is great.  I followed the recipe exactly and made no changes.  It is a pretty soup that can be garnished with many things like green onion, bacon bits, or thyme.  I've never used Marjoram before, but now I will be trying it in other dishes since it was so good.  My mom hates butternut squash, but loved this soup!  We all agree that this would be a good starter soup to a pork, turkey or roast.  It's very rich, so you only need to serve about 1/2 to 3/4 cup per person.

It's my first time cooking with butternut squash and I have to say that I joined just so I can write this review! It was wonderful! My fiance loved it! I cut the squash in half and scraped out the seeds, drizzled some olive oil and sprinkled some salt, then baked them, upside down for 45 mins at 180Â°C. I added just 3 bouillon cubes since the ones we get here seem large, and 1.5 of the cream cheese and 1/4 t of cayenne.  Next time, I plan to use 1 package of cream cheese, and 2 bouillon cubes. I plan on including this into my Thanksgiving menu this year!

userID:

Display Name:
Betty Dawe
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/193835.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this soup twice now. The first time, exactly as specified. It was good, but I felt like there could've been another layer of flavor added. Tonight, I tweaked it a little and WOW! What a difference. My husband loved it so much, there wasn't any left over to freeze this time.
First of all, let me say that I halved the recipe as there are only two of us - it still comes out beautifully.
Here's what I did:
After sauteeing the onions in (real) butter, deglaze the pot with 1/2c. white wine. I substituted Herbs de Provenc for the marjoram and I roasted the squash.
The biggest difference is that I added about 2Tbl honey to the soup after it was blended. It adds a subtle sweetness that compliments the soup without making it sweet, and I grated fresh nutmeg over the top of the bowls before serving.     
What a lovely soup on a cold, rainy fall day. I will definately make this again.

text:
WARNING!!  THIS SOUP IS HABIT FORMING.  This recipe is incredible.  I as many, roasted the squash in the oven first.  I also used only half the cream cheese.  While I was making it, my 12 year old son kept saying, "I won't like it".  He now says it is the best thing I have ever made, after my burgers of course.  Also, don't think of this recipe as only a soup.  We have found it makes an excellent sauce also.  Use the leftovers to pour over other items.  I made omlettes the day after the soup and my wife immediately poured some soup over it.  It was quite delicious.  

I have now made it 3 weeks running.  And the family still wants more.  Use it for Eggs Benedict in place of the Hollandaise.  Delicious

city:

None
text:
This soup makes me feel like I'm eating in a restaurant each time I make it. I prefer using pre-cut squash to save time. 2LBs is about 6 cups. I add an apple, and use 2 - 14.5oz cans of low sodium, fat free broth. I also reduce the cream cheese to 4-6 ounces. My kids don't like spicy, my 1st born likes nutmeg in his, and DH likes Hot Madras Curry in his, so I put those and cayenne on the side. I serve with French bread (tried sourdough, and we feel it's too tangy for this soup). Thanks for the keeper!

My husband is willing to try anything, but is very selective with his feedback.  He literally said, "this is the best soup I have ever tasted," after the first few bites.    I followed recipe for the most part but used only about 6 oz of cream cheese (rather than 16 oz), and substituted a vegetable bouillon (without MSG or other preservatives) for the chicken bouillon.  The VitaMix blender was awesome to puree, and all I can say is that it was phenomenal.  Thanks for the great recipe.

text:
I roasted the squash in the oven like other reviewers had suggested and it was super easy to skin and cube up to add to the soup. I also used vegetable stock to make it vegetarian and only added one package of cream cheese. (And some garlic. I put garlic in just about everything.) The first night it was kind of bland, so next time I'll either add more spices or simmer spices in the vegetable stock while the squash roasts. I also felt like it was a bit too thick, so next time I'll halve the cream cheese. Or make it ahead of time. ANYWAY. The second day it was awesome! I added about a cup more broth and it's fantastic.

text:
This soup is a rarity on this site -- the recipe is nearly perfect as-is. The only changes truly are personal preference tweaks, but no changes are needed. I created a custom version (see custom tab) that incorporates the things I changed and is a generalized version for all winter squash. Basically I replaced margarine for butter, replaced cream cheese for Neufchatel + decreasing quantity by 1/2 and I added some cinnamon. Very minor!

text:
I read this recipe and then read of few of the reviews and made some changes.  I baked the butternut squash with olive oil, salt, pepper and crushed garlic for 1 hour @ 350 degrees.  I added 1/2 sliced apple.  I used 32 oz. of chicken broth because I knew if I didn't use the entire package for this recipe it would end up going to waste.  I blended the soup with a hand blender (easy!) I didn't have any cayenne pepper so I used extra ground pepper and a little bit of ginger.  I also left out the cream cheese because it was creamy enough and the butter (I used butter instead of margarine) added enough calories and fat.  Next time, I will try olive oil instead of butter.  It was sooo good!!!

My family LOVES this recipe.  I've made it several times and usually double it.  I do only a couple of things differently.  First off I don't ever use margarine, so I used butter instead. I have used low fat cream cheese on occasion and it doesn't seem to make a difference.  Either way, with or without my changes this soup is amazing!

text:
Absolutely delicious!  I baked the squash in the oven as others suggested and that was wonderful and easy.  I did not measure my onions, just chopped up two smallish onions, so I'm sure I had more than 6 T, but I like savory soups, so I did that on purpose.  I also only added a couple ounces of Neufchatel cheese - a little less fattening than cream cheese.  I added just enough to change the color of the soup and pureed it all together.  It was not sweet at all (may have been with all the cream cheese) - it was nice and savory, the way I like it.  The cayenne was delicious in it.  I make soup from summer squash pretty regularly, but I liked this even better.  My husband raved and my kids even liked it - I just added a little milk to their bowl to bring down the spice a bit (they are 3 and 5), but a little dab of sour cream would have been great for a garnish for them too, if I'd had some.  I will definitely make this many more times...thank you for the recipe!

text:
I just made this today and we loved it! I followed advice from others to bake the squash because it brings out the flavor and makes it easy to work with. I softened the onions in butter then added the water and bouillon cubes with the spices. I used rubbed sage because I didn't have marjoram and added a pinch of nutmeg. Also upped the cayenne just a bit to our taste. Then I scooped out the baked squash and added to the mix w/ the cream cheese. I used my hand blender to puree it altogether. Excellent recipe! To make a beautiful presentation you could swirl a tsp. of cream around the top of the soup. If you love squash this is a must try. Thanks for the great soup recipe.

This soup is delicious, and pretty easy to make, but VERY creamy.  I even followed the suggestion of others and only used one package of light cream cheese, and was still VERY rich!!  In the future I'll only use a spoonful of cream cheese!  I also added a lot more cayenne (maybe a 1/2 a teaspoon), and the cayenne flavor was strong (yet delicious).  I also baked the squash for maybe 45 minutes before, makes it easier to peel & cut.  Will do it again, with modifications.

text:
This makes a wonderful soup! Excellent for cold fall & winter days.

To make it more smooth, I'll sometimes substitute the cream cheese with some whipping cream or canned milk. I also like to put fresh spices into a cheesecloth that I can take out at the end. This makes the soup more uniform in color and flavor. When I serve it, I like to save some of the cream/milk and give the soup an artistic swirl.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was fantastic. The only thing I varied was the cream cheese - used 1 pkg (half of the standard recipe amount). I added more black and cayenne pepper than suggested - just a matter of taste - started with the recipe amounts and just added a bit at a time until it was just right. I tasted the soup to make sure it was OK and I just couldn't stop! Everyone at our Thanksgiving table loved it - even the guys who didn't think they wanted to try it. It is pretty easy too - a bit of a pain to pour into the blender, mix, pour back into pan - but overall it's easy and quick and DELICIOUS. Enjoy!!

text:
I just made this and... wow.  It was a huge hit.  I did make some changes.  I only used about 6 oz. cream cheese.  I used sage instead of marjoram (b/c sage and butternut squash were made to go together) and I used more like 1 1/2 tsp.  I used a bit extra black and cayenne pepper.  AND I used about 1/4 cup parmesan which added a nice extra flavor.  I boiled the squash before working with it to soften it up.  So I cut the stovetop cooking time down to 15 minutes. 

This was so easy and so decadent.  I'll definitely make again. But it is FILLING!

text:
Delicious!
I changed it up by using low-fat cream cheese and only 1 package of it.
Additionally, I cooked my squash in the microwave (ten minutes, cut in half with 1/4 inch of water) while I prepared the other ingredients. I also put the liquids in my sauce pan after lightly sauteing the onions. Then scraped out the squash with a spoon and everything went into my Vita-mix blender and I blended for one minute.

Fabulous consistency: creamy, rich and smooth. For my portion I added a couple extra dashes of cayenne, as I like it on the spicy side.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this tonight and can't wait to share it with friends tomorrow.  It's fabulous as is, but I made some changes to suit my own tastes.  I roasted the peeled and diced squash, along with an acorn squash and 2 sweet potatoes, tossed in olive oil, garlic powder, poultry seasoning, sea salt and black pepper for 45 minutes.  With an immersion blender I pureed the vegetables with 48 oz chicken broth, 1 pkg. cream cheese and 1.5 cups skim milk.  I substituted red pepper flakes for the cayenne that I didn't have.  This is a wonderful, velvety recipe!  An easy way to peel the squash is with a vegetable peeler.  It didn't take any longer than a potato.

text:
This soup is fantastic! Especially after it's a day or two old. I took other recommendations and cut two large butternut squash in half, placed them face down and baked on 375 for 30 min... scooped out the inside and blended it in a blender with the cream cheese in batches. I seasoned just as recommended and it really didn't need anything extra. I've been eating the left overs for two days now with rolls. It gets better the longer it sits. I will definitely make this again!!!

text:
Great Recipe, I normally make Squash soup all the time with the basic but wanted to try this recipe, while I slightly deviated it was still great. I added only about 2 Tbs spoon of cream cheese, and also added heavy whipping cream. I chopped about 2 tbls spoon worth of fresh chicken in small bits with half a handful of pasta. This allowed the soup to thicken real nicely. The chicken bouillon was reduced slightly to reduce the sodium content. The soup was rich and creamy with small bits of chicken, and the occasosional penne pasta bit.

text:
This recipe is fantastic!  I have made this soup twice, and everyone who tries it loves it!  I must admit that I made a few changes.  I roast the squash first, and I add in extra cayenne pepper and some curry powder (I like mine with a little kick).  But my biggest change is that I cut down the cream cheese significantly - I only use 4 oz (half of a block), and it comes out perfect.  Smooth, creamy, and delicious.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Roasted the squash split lengthwise face down at 375 for 45 minutes first; makes the skin easy to peel and the squash easy to scoop. And cuts the boiling time down to only about 5 minutes once you add to the chicken broth. I cut the cream cheese in half, I used three cans of chicken broth. PHENOMENAL. I made this for a potluck dinner last month and it was the only soup that was really touched out of four choices - everyone loved it. Roommates and friends have requested it 4 other times since. Super easy to make (about 30 minutes after roasting) and VERY delicious.

text:
Overall very good soup, but I did make some adjustments.  First, I roasted my squash is the oven brushing it lightly with olive oil and the sprinkling it with salt and pepper.  I only used one half of one cream cheese block, 4oz I guess.  It was still very rich and creamy.  I can't imagine liking it if I used the orignal two cream cheese blocks that the recipe calls for.  Sometimes less is more.  Also, I used chicken broth and omitted the bouillion.  I loved the kick the cayanne pepper lends to this soup.  Delicious.

Display Name:
Cynthia

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious soup, especially because it is a little bit different from other butternut squash soup recipes.  I'm a vegetarian, so I made it with vegetable broth, and that worked well.  As others have mentioned, I used less cream cheese, actually only about 1/4 of a block of neufchatel.  I would recommend only using about this much when you initially blend the soup.  You can always put it back in the blender again with a bit more cream cheese if you decide you want more, but you can't take out the cream cheese once you've blended it in.  Also, I found the soup a little bit thick, so I added a little bit more vegetable broth (about 3/4 cup) to the soup once it was entirely done and blended.  That thinned it out, and it was great!
Review:

5

Your house will smell like heaven and it makes it makes it taste so much better.  This is a new family recipe that will be at every Thanksgiving from now on.

This soup was delicious, but since I altered the recipe based on others' reviews, I only gave it 4 stars. Served it with warm rolls. Fantastic!

Excellent!Both my husband and I loved it.

text:
Wow, this was definitely a keeper.  To make it easier, I split the squash and baked it ahead of time.  Also, after sauteing the onion, I just threw the rest in the crock pot and mixed it up with the hand blender.  I really liked the bite the cayenne gave it, but will use less next time because it was a bit too spicy for my little kids.  Also used a little less cream cheese than called for, but probably wouldn't do without it entirely.  The texture was still nice without, but the taste was greatly improved by adding cream cheese (of course, I think EVERYTHING is better with a little cream cheese). Really great comfort food and easy too!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I used two medium-sized butternut squashes, halved them, and roasted them for 35min in 350F, cut side down, with chopped garlic, salt, and pepper. I also eliminated the marjoram, used 4c chicken stock, and added only 4oz fat-free cream cheese. I tried it without the cream cheese and it was just as good. Since the butternut was already pretty tender from the oven, I only brought to a boil for a few minutes, then used an immersion blender to blend it all. Finally, I added the cream cheese at the end so it wouldn't curdle. Overall, very good. It was missing just a little something though...I wonder what it'd be like with a little sharp cheddar...I'll report back :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really good recipe.  It would probably have been fine as is, but we cooks love to tinker!  I roasted the squash with butter, salt, pepper & brown sugar for 40 minutes at 350.  I sauted onion, garlic and 1 small apple in the butter and then added almost a cup of apple cidar (all I had left) and 2 cups water to the onion mixture.  I added chicken boullion, @ 2 cups of leftover chicken, oregano, red pepper, salt & black pepper.  I used only 1 package of cream cheese and only had 1 medium squash, so blended it and added it.  I also like to chew my soup so threw in some leftover brown rice.  The consistency was just right, but a little sweet.  Maybe I'll leave out the cidar next time.  Everyone liked it very much.  Thank you for the recipe.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This is our family's all-time favorite allrecipes.com recipe--we've eaten it frequently since first discovering it (and allrecipes.com) more than 2 years ago. The only change we've made was to make it the way our friend first fixed it for us: a block of low-fat cream cheese and a block of silken tofu instead of the 2 blocks of cream cheese. It doesn't alter the taste, but adds a little extra protein. My toddler LOVES this soup and requests it often. Peeling and cubing the squash is time consuming, but the soup freezes well before the addition of the cheese, so I often devote an afternoon to the beloved butternut!

text:
This recipe is pretty good.  The only kind of squash I've ever had before was fried squash and it was less than tasty.  I give 4 stars because I think it needs to have something in it...I added a little more cayenne pepper and salt and pepper to taste when i was finished cooking it.  Also, I added a can of kidney beans (well rinsed)-I think this soup would also be a good base for a chowder or creamy stew.  Its also very good for dipping a crusty french or sourdough bread.  Overall pretty good-just may need to do some tweaking based on your own tastes.

This stuff is fantastic!  I get cravings for it.  I cut the cream cheese in half and it's still too rich to eat plain, but I use it as a dip for sourdough bread and it's perfect.  My husband, who dislikes squash, eats this willingly because the cream cheese covers up the squash taste.  One warning: you have to use a good squash or the recipe is ruined!  Out of the many times I made this, it has come out all wrong once (strangely sweet) and I had to throw it out.  I'm pretty sure the squash was at fault.

text:
This is the best butternut squash soup I have ever tasted.  I have given this recipe to family, friends, and co-workers who all agree it is wonderful.  I prepare the squash by using a vegetable peeler and peel the skin and then cut in half, scoop out the seeds and cut the squash into 1 inch pieces. I also use 6 oz of cream or neufactual cheese.  My husband loves this soup and I make it at lease 5 times (if not more) during fall and winter.

text:
When I received an immersion blender as a gift for my birthday, the first recipe I tried was this one, and all of the rave reviews are true... this is an amazing soup.  The first time I tried it, I used one 8 oz package (it was too rich)  The second time (I must admit, a few days later), I used half of a package (4 oz) and it turned out much better.  I can't even imagine trying it with the two!  Second admission.. I licked the bowl! It's that good.

One thing of note: after the first try, I now always leave out the onion/butter step.  I didn't like finding little pieces of onion in an otherwise smooth soup.
